{{Politics of Somalia}} {{main|Somali Civil War|Disarmament in Somalia}}
The '''2007 [[Somalia|Somali]] National Reconciliation Conference''' was held from 15 July 2007 until 30 August 2007<sup>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200708290891.html]</sup> in [[Mogadishu]]; it was announced on 1 March 2007 by [[Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed]], the [[List of Presidents of Somalia|President]] of the [[Transitional Federal Government]] (TFG).<sup>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120206133001/http://www.somalinet.com/news/world/Somalia/8052] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200703030187.html]</sup>
==Preparations==
More than 3,000 people from all of Somalia's [[regions of Somalia|regions]] and [[Somali clans|clans]] as well as from the [[Somali diaspora]] participated.<sup>[http://english.people.com.cn/200703/19/eng20070319_359027.html]</sup> The [[United States]] had announced their support for the conference.<sup>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-03/22/content_5878995.htm]</sup> Moderate Islamists in exile in [[Eritrea]] had also been invited,<sup>[http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/6214470.html]</sup> but had refused to attend.
It was originally planned to be held from 16 April until mid-June, but was postponed thrice, first to 15 May 2007,<sup>[http://english.people.com.cn/200704/12/eng20070412_365714.html]</sup> then to 14 June 2007<sup>[http://english.people.com.cn/200704/19/eng20070419_367801.html]</sup> and finally to 15 July 2007.<sup>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6747999.stm]</sup>
==Events== When the conference finally opened on 15 July 2007, it immediately adjourned until 19 July 2007 to allow for more delegates to arrive, since the moderate Islamists had not yet ended their boycott of the conference.<sup>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6899684.stm]</sup> The conference building was being attacked with mortars on that date, as well, and again on 17 July 2007.<sup>[http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/6217948.html]</sup>
The conference eventually opened for real on 19 July 2007; however, moderate Islamists and [[Hawiye]] clan elders still boycotted it, claiming that the venue were not neutral. Islamists have scheduled a conference in [[Asmara]] instead.
There was an 11-point program to be discussed at the conference, including the holding of elections.<sup>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6905958.stm]</sup> According to commentators, little was achieved at the conference.<sup>[http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=74031]</sup>
==See also== * [[2002 Somali Reconciliation Conference]]
==Further reading== * "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070819134535/http://voanews.com/english/Africa/2007-07-19-voa7.cfm Diplomat Optimistic Somalia Conference Will Bring True Peace]" in Voice of America news, July 19, 2007. * "[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/16/world/africa/16somalia.html Somalia Reconciliation Conference Opens, but Soon Stalls]" in The New York Times, July 16, 2007. * "[http://allafrica.com/stories/200707161100.html Somaliland Boycotts to Attend the Reconciliation Conference]" in allAfrica.com, July 15, 2007.

''This article covers rioting in July and August. For riots linked to the City Hall protests, see [[Belfast City Hall flag protests]].'' {{Infobox civil conflict |title = 2013 Belfast riots |partof = |image = |caption = |date = 12-17 July 2013
9 August 2013 |place = [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland |coordinates = |causes = |goals = |methods = [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]], [[riot]]ing |status = |result = * At least 88 police officers injured * At least two civilians injured * Extra police officers deployed in Northern Ireland * Around 200 arrests |side1 = |side2 = |side3 = |leadfigures1 = |leadfigures2 = |leadfigures3 = |howmany1 = |howmany2 = |howmany3 = |casualties1 = |casualties2 = |casualties3 = |casualties_label = |notes = }} The '''2013 Belfast riots''' was a series of riots taking place in [[Belfast]] in [[Northern Ireland]]. They came months after the [[Belfast City Hall flag protests]] ignited rioting. ==July riots== Rioting broke out following the [[The Twelfth|12 July Orange Order]] parade, when local [[Orange Order|Orangemen]] were barred from returning via their traditional route via the Catholic-populated [[Ardoyne]] in north Belfast, which ignited protests from [[Ulster loyalism|loyalists]]. Trouble also spread to south and east Belfast.{{cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/13/world/europe/northern-ireland-unrest/index.html|title=Extra police sent to Northern Ireland after Belfast rioting - CNN|first=By Peter Taggart and Laura Smith-Spark,|last=CNN|publisher=}} The [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] (PSNI) fired about 20 plastic baton rounds at rioters and used two mobile water cannons. For several hours they dealt with loyalists and [[Irish nationalist|nationalists]] exchanging missiles across the police line, and at one point a group of loyalists used [[ceremonial weapon|ceremonial swords]] to attack the police lines. [[Nigel Dodds]], the unionist MP for Belfast North, was injured and hospitalised when struck in the head by a missile when he was trying to negotiate with police officers in Woodvale Avenue. 32 officers were hurt.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/jul/13/northern-ireland-police-loyalist-rioting|title=Northern Ireland police call Belfast rioting 'shameful and disgraceful'|first=Henry|last=McDonald|date=13 July 2013|website=the Guardian}} The PSNI Chief Constable called 400 extra police officers from England, Scotland and Wales to deal with the situation - more than 600 from the British mainland were already supporting the PSNI beforehand. It was an unprecedented move - in the past, and during [[the Troubles]], the [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]] (RUC) never called in extra police but used the [[British Army]] soldiers, who withdrew from Northern Ireland in 2007. By the end of August, 106 arrests were made and 77 were charged.https://www.rte.ie/news/2013/0827/470584-more-than-100-arrested-over-unionist-riots/ ==August riots== Violent clashes broke out on the evening of Friday 9 August when loyalists attempted to prevent a parade of 5,000 [[Irish republican]] marking the anniversary of [[Operation Demetrius|internment in 1971]] through the city centre. The parade was a joint alliance of dissident groups which included the [[32 County Sovereignty Movement]], the political wing of the [[New IRA]]. It was legally given permission but up to 1,000 loyalists blocked their route at around 6 pm and attacked riot police around Royal Avenue/North Street, and clashes between loyalists and nationalists took place.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/northernireland/10234703/56-police-hurt-in-Belfast-riots.html|title=56 police hurt in Belfast riots|first=|last=Agencies|date=10 August 2013|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}} By an hour later, PSNI officers and armoured vehicles blocked the republican parade in North Queen Street in [[New Lodge, Belfast|New Lodge]]. This would become a second stand-off from the one around Royal Avenue involving loyalists.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/aug/09/northen-ireland-belfast-riots-loyalist-republican|title=Belfast loyalists riot as they attempt to prevent republican march|first=Henry|last=McDonald|date=9 August 2013|website=the Guardian}} The parade organisers decided to avoid Royal Avenue and take a route via Carrick Hill and Millfield, near the city centre, towards west Belfast. "Serious disorder" took place on these roads as riot police separated the two groups. The protesters were then pushed back towards the [[Shankill Road]] area.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-23645607|title=56 officers hurt in Belfast riots|date=10 August 2013|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} The PSNI fired 26 plastic baton rounds and deployed two water cannons. [[Michael Copeland (politician)|Michael Copeland]], an [[Ulster Unionist Party]] (UUP) politician, claimed that he and his family members were assaulted by police in Royal Avenue. In total, 56 police officers and two civilians were injured.{{cite web|url=https://www.channel4.com/news/northern-ireland-belfast-riot-police-loyalist-parade-video|title=‘Mindless anarchy’: 56 officers hurt in Belfast violence|publisher=}} Northern Ireland Secretary [[Theresa Villiers]] described the violence as "shameful". Within four days the PSNI arrested 90 people of which 66 were charged, and released photos of other wanted offenders.https://www.thejournal.ie/people-wanted-over-belfast-rioting-1034447-Aug2013/#slide-slideshow14 ==See also== *[[Belfast City Hall flag protests]] *[[2012 North Belfast riots]] *[[2011 Northern Ireland riots]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:2013 in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:2013 riots]] [[Category:Ethnic riots]] [[Category:History of Belfast]] [[Category:Political riots]] [[Category:Protests in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:August 2013 events in Europe]] [[Category:August 2013 events]] [[Category:Orange Order]]

{{Use British English|date=April 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[File:mossbourne community academy 1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Mossbourne Community Academy]], the successor to [[Hackney Downs School]] (October 2005)]]
'''Academy schools''' are [[State-funded schools (England)|state-funded schools]] in [[England]] which are directly funded by the [[Department for Education]] and independent of [[local authority]] control. The terms of the arrangements are set out in individual Academy Funding Agreements.<ref name="IndividualFundingAgreements">{{cite web|title=What is a Funding Agreement? {{!}} a can of worms|url=http://davidwolfe.org.uk/wordpress/archives/241|website=davidwolfe.org.uk|accessdate=4 January 2018|date=8 October 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180104192422/http://davidwolfe.org.uk/wordpress/archives/241|archivedate=4 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Most academies are [[secondary school]]s (and most secondary schools are academies). However, slightly more than 25% of [[primary school]]s (4,363 as of December 2017<ref>{{cite web|title=Schools, pupils, and their characteristics (Official Statistics)|url=http://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/schools-pupils-and-their-characteristics-january-2012|date=13 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180114020225/https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/schools-pupils-and-their-characteristics-january-2012|archivedate=14 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>), as well as some of the remaining [[first school|first]], [[middle school|middle]] and secondary schools, are also academies.
Academies are self-governing [[non-profit]] [[Charitable trusts in English law|charitable trusts]] and may receive additional support from personal or corporate sponsors, either financially or in kind.<ref name=CharityCommission>{{cite web|title=Charities and charity trustees: an introduction for school governors|url=http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/Charity_requirements_guidance/Specialist_guidance/Education/introduction_for_school_governors.aspx|work=Charity Commission website|publisher=Charity Commission|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref> They do not have to follow the [[National Curriculum for England|National Curriculum]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/types-of-school/academies|title=Types of school - Academies|accessdate=16 March 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160316211956/https://www.gov.uk/types-of-school/academies|archivedate=16 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> but do have to ensure that their curriculum is broad and balanced,<ref name="AcademiesAct2010Section1">{{cite web|title=Academies Act 2010, Section 1|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2010/32/section/1|publisher=Gov.uk|accessdate=18 March 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305211742/http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2010/32/section/1|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and that it includes the core subjects of mathematics and English.<ref name="AcademyFundingAgreement">{{cite web|title=Academy and Free School Master Funding Agreement|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/388471/Academy_and_free_school_-_master_funding_agreement.pdf|publisher=Gov.uk|accessdate=18 March 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151010032820/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/388471/Academy_and_free_school_-_master_funding_agreement.pdf|archivedate=10 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> They are subject to inspection by [[Ofsted]].
==Types== The following are all types of academy:<ref name=AcademyTypes>{{cite web|title=Types of academy |url=http://www.ssatuk.co.uk/ssat/support/academies/about-academies/types-of-academy/ |work=SSAT Website |publisher=Specialist Schools and Academies Trust |accessdate=3 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503185240/http://www.ssatuk.co.uk/ssat/support/academies/about-academies/types-of-academy/ |archivedate=3 May 2014 |df= }}</ref>
* '''Sponsored academy''': A formerly [[maintained school]] that has been transformed to academy status as part of a government intervention strategy. They are consequently run by a Government-approved sponsor.<ref>{{cite web|title=Academy sponsorship|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/academy-sponsorship|work=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503185227/https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/academy-sponsorship|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> They are sometimes referred to as '''traditional academies'''.<ref name=schoolTypes>{{cite web|title=Comparison of Different School Type|url=http://www.newschoolsnetwork.org/sites/default/files/files/pdf/Differences%20across%20school%20types.pdf|work=NSN website|publisher=New Schools Network|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref> * '''Converter academy''': A formerly [[maintained school]] that has ''voluntarily'' converted to academy status. It is not necessary for a converter academy to have a sponsor.<ref name=conversionProcess>{{cite web|title=Academy conversion process|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/academy-conversion-process|work=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503185031/https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/academy-conversion-process|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * '''[[Free school (England)|Free school]]''': Free schools are new academies established since 2011 via the Free School Programme.<ref name=FreeSchoolDefn>{{cite web|title=Education Terms: Free Schools|url=http://www.education.gov.uk/vocabularies/educationtermsandtags/7123|work=DfE Website|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503170022/http://www.education.gov.uk/vocabularies/educationtermsandtags/7123|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> From May 2015, usage of the term was also extended to new academies set up via a Local Authority competition.<ref name=FreeSchoolPresumption>{{cite web|title=The free school presumption|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/451377/Academy_and_free_school_presumption_departmental_advice_2.pdf|website=Gov.uk|accessdate=16 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111142835/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/451377/Academy_and_free_school_presumption_departmental_advice_2.pdf|archivedate=11 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The majority of free schools are similar in size and shape to other types of academy. However, the following are distinctive sub-types of free school:<ref name="AcademyTypes"/> ** '''[[Studio school]]''': A small free school, usually with around 300 pupils, using project-based learning<ref name=GovTypesOfSchool>{{cite web|title=Types of school|url=https://www.gov.uk/types-of-school/free-schools|work=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=4 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219225058/https://www.gov.uk/types-of-school/free-schools|archivedate=19 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ** '''[[University Technical College]]''': A free school for the 14-18 age group, specialising in practical, employment focused subjects, sponsored by a university, employer or [[further education college]].<ref name="GovTypesOfSchool"/><ref name=UTCColleges>{{cite web|title=UTC Colleges Overview|url=http://www.utcolleges.org/about/overview/|website=UTC Colleges|publisher=Baker Dearing Educational Trust|accessdate=16 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150716153058/http://www.utcolleges.org/about/overview/|archivedate=16 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * '''Faith academy''':An academy with an official [[Faith school|faith designation]].<ref name=FaithAcademy1>{{cite web|title='Faith' academy faces criticism|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/leicestershire/4360467.stm|work=BBC News website|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref><ref name=TelegraphFaithAcademy>{{cite news|last=Ward|first=Victoria|title=Test case could dictate admissions policy in faith schools|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/9681719/Test-case-could-dictate-admissions-policy-in-faith-schools.html|accessdate=4 May 2014|date=15 Nov 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140602070119/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/9681719/Test-case-could-dictate-admissions-policy-in-faith-schools.html|archivedate=2 June 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * '''[[Co-operative academy]]''': An academy that uses an alternative [[co-operative]] academy agreement. {{anchor|chain}}An academy trust that operates more than one academy is known as an '''Academy Chain''', although sometimes the terms '''Academy Group''' or '''Academy Federation''' are used instead. An Academy Chain is a group of schools working together under a shared academy structure that is either an '''Umbrella Trust''' or a '''Multi-Academy Trust (MAT)'''.<ref name=SSATChains>{{cite web|title=Academy Chains|url=http://www.ssatuk.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Academy-Chains-and-Groups.pdf|work=SSAT UK website|publisher=Specialist Schools and Academies Trust|accessdate=4 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504105416/http://www.ssatuk.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Academy-Chains-and-Groups.pdf|archivedate=4 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=BecomeAcademyDfe>{{cite web|title=Become an academy: information for schools|url=https://www.gov.uk/become-an-academy-information-for-schools|work=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=4 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504104002/https://www.gov.uk/become-an-academy-information-for-schools|archivedate=4 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Features== {{anchor|Academy Agreement}} An academy is governed by the Academy Agreement it makes with the Department for Education, and at that point it severs connections with the local education authority. The current advisory text is the ''Academy and free school: master funding agreement'' dated March 2018.<ref name="Agreement">{{cite web|title=Academy and free school-master funding agreement|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/388471/Academy_and_free_school_-_master_funding_agreement.pdf|website=www.gov.uk|accessdate=3 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425083310/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/388471/Academy_and_free_school_-_master_funding_agreement.pdf|archivedate=25 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="ws">{{cite web|title=Changes to DfE funding agreements for academies|url=https://www.wrigleys.co.uk/news/education/changes-to-dfe-funding-agreements-for-academies/|website=Wrigleys Solicitors|accessdate=3 January 2018|location=Leeds|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180104192327/https://www.wrigleys.co.uk/news/education/changes-to-dfe-funding-agreements-for-academies/|archivedate=4 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The governors of the academy are obliged to publish an annual report and accounts, that are open to scrutiny.<ref name="AReport">{{cite web|title=Academy and free school-master funding agreement- 4.23|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/388471/Academy_and_free_school_-_master_funding_agreement.pdf|website=www.gov.uk|accessdate=3 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425083310/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/388471/Academy_and_free_school_-_master_funding_agreement.pdf|archivedate=25 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
All academies are expected to follow a broad and balanced curriculum but many have a particular focus on, or formal [[Specialist schools programme|specialism]] in, one or more areas such as science; arts; business and enterprise; computing; engineering; mathematics; modern foreign languages; performing arts; sport; or technology. Although academies are required to follow the [[National Curriculum for England|National Curriculum]] in the core subjects of maths, English and science,<ref name="bedell" /> they are otherwise free to innovate; however, as they participate in the same [[Key Stage 3]] and [[GCSE]] exams as other English schools, they teach a curriculum very similar to [[maintained school]]s, with only small variations.<ref>{{cite web|title=How much do academies use their legal ‘freedoms’ in practice {{!}} a can of worms|url=http://davidwolfe.org.uk/wordpress/archives/1418|website=davidwolfe.org.uk|accessdate=3 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180104194015/http://davidwolfe.org.uk/wordpress/archives/1418|archivedate=4 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Like other state-funded schools, academies are required to adhere to the National Admissions Code, although newly established academies with a faith designation are subject to the [[The 50% Rule|50% Rule]] requiring them to allocate at least half of their places without reference to faith.<ref name=admissionsCode>{{cite web|title=School admissions code|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/school-admissions-code|work=gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=4 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421084106/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/school-admissions-code|archivedate=21 April 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In terms of their governance, academies are established as [[companies limited by guarantee]] with a Board of Directors that acts as a Trust. The '''Academy Trust''' has [[exempt charity]] status, regulated by the Department for Education.<ref name="CharityCommission" /> The trustees are legally, but not financially, accountable for the operation of the academy. The Trust serves as the legal entity of which the school is part. The trustees oversee the running of the school, sometimes delegating responsibility to a '''local governing body''' which they appoint.{{anchor|local governing body}} The day-to-day management of the school is, as in most schools, conducted by the [[Head teacher|Head Teacher]] and their senior management team.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
In '''Sponsored Academies''', the sponsor is able to influence the process of establishing the school, including its curriculum, ethos, specialism and building (if a new one is built). The sponsor also has the power to appoint [[school governors|governors]] to the academy's governing body.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
==History== The [[Blair administration|Labour Government under Tony Blair]] established academies through the [[Learning and Skills Act 2000]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2000/00021--i.htm#130 |title=Learning and Skills Act 2000 (c. 21) |publisher=Opsi.gov.uk |date=17 August 2011 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121075842/http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2000/00021--i.htm#130 |archivedate=21 November 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> which amended the section of the [[Education Act 1996]] relating to [[City Technology College]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts1996/96056-cc.htm |title=Education Act 1996 (c. 56) |publisher=Opsi.gov.uk |date=17 August 2011 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416093050/http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts1996/96056-cc.htm |archivedate=16 April 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They were first announced in a speech by [[David Blunkett]], then [[Secretary of State for Education and Skills]], in 2000.<ref name=announcement>{{cite news|last=Carvel|first=John|title=Blunkett plans network of city academies|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/mar/15/schools.news|accessdate=4 May 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=15 Mar 2000|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504192442/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/mar/15/schools.news|archivedate=4 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=TESAnnouncement>{{cite news|title=Blessed be the school sponsor|url=http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=332257|accessdate=4 May 2014|newspaper=Times Educational Supplement|date=17 Mar 2000|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504192033/http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=332257|archivedate=4 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/925378.stm |title=EDUCATION | 'City academies' to tackle school failure |publisher=BBC News |date=15 September 2000 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040220082603/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/925378.stm |archivedate=20 February 2004 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He said that their aim was "to improve pupil performance and break the cycle of low expectations." As of 2018 many academies are struggling financially and running deficits.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/03/academies-schools-deficit-bailout Dozens of academy schools need bailouts from taxpayers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180203152101/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/03/academies-schools-deficit-bailout |date=3 February 2018 }} ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref>
The chief architect of the policy was [[Andrew Adonis]] (now Lord Adonis, formerly Secretary of State at the [[Department for Transport]]) in his capacity as education advisor to the Prime Minister in the late 1990s.<ref name="indie_faq"> {{cite news |last = Garner |first = Richard |title = The Big Question: What are academy schools, and is their future under threat? |publisher = ''[[The Independent]]'' |date = 8 October 2008 |url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/the-big-question-what-are-academy-schools-and-is-their-future-under-threat-954486.html |accessdate = 31 December 2009 |location = London |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091005212902/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/the-big-question-what-are-academy-schools-and-is-their-future-under-threat-954486.html |archivedate = 5 October 2009 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
Academies were known as '''City Academies''' for the first few years, but the term was changed to '''Academies''' by an [[law|amendment]] in the [[Education Act 2002]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2002/20032--j.htm |title=Education Act 2002 (c. 32) |publisher=Opsi.gov.uk |date=17 August 2011 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930180256/http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2002/20032--j.htm |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The term '''Sponsored Academies''' was applied retrospectively to this type of academy, to distinguish it from other [[Academy (English school)#Types of Academy|types of academy]] that were enabled later.
===Sponsored academies=== {{anchor|Sponsored Academy}} Sponsored Academies originally needed a ''private'' sponsor who could be an individual (such as [[Sir David Garrard]], who sponsors [[Business Academy Bexley]]), organisations such as the [[United Learning Trust]], mission-driven businesses such as [[The Co-operative Group]] or [[outsourcing]] for-profit businesses such as [[Amey plc]]). These sponsors were expected to bring "the best of private-sector best practice and innovative management" to academies, "often in marked contrast to the lack of leadership experienced by the failing schools that academies have replaced" (known as '''predecessor schools''').<ref name=PYB2008>{{cite web|title=BSF — HOW TO SPONSOR AN ACADEMY OR A SPECIALIST SCHOOL. A GUIDE FOR SPONSORS|url=http://www.parliamentaryyearbook2008.co.uk/CP/how-to-sponsor-an-academy.html|work=Parliamentary Year Book 2008|publisher=Blakes|accessdate=4 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018113652/http://www.parliamentaryyearbook2008.co.uk/CP/how-to-sponsor-an-academy.html|archivedate=18 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> They were originally required to contribute 10% of the academy's capital costs (up to a maximum of £2m). The remainder of the capital and running costs were met by the state in the usual way for UK state schools through grants funded by the local authority.
The Government later removed the requirement for financial investment by a private sponsor in a move to encourage successful existing schools and charities to become sponsors.
Sponsored Academies typically replaced one or more existing schools, but some were newly established. They were intended to address the problem of entrenched failure within English schools with low academic achievement, or schools situated in communities with low academic aspirations. Often these schools had been placed in "[[special measures]]" after an Ofsted inspection, as has been the case for schools in the Co-op Academies Trust (one of the larger business-supported trusts).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://get-information-schools.service.gov.uk/Groups/Group/Details/2777#list|title=THE CO-OPERATIVE ACADEMIES TRUST - GOV.UK|author=|date=|website=get-information-schools.service.gov.uk|accessdate=28 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180106063504/https://get-information-schools.service.gov.uk/Groups/Group/Details/2777#list|archivedate=6 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> They were expected to be creative and innovative because of their financial and academic freedoms, in order to deal with the long-term issues they were intended to solve.<ref name=CH4faqs>{{cite web|title=Q&A: city academies|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/society/education/qa+city+academies/1071547.html|work=Channel 4 News website|publisher=Channel 4|accessdate=4 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504222839/http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/society/education/qa+city+academies/1071547.html|archivedate=4 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Originally all Sponsored Academies had to have a curriculum specialism within the English [[specialist school|Specialist Schools Programme (SSP)]].<ref name="Standards Site">{{cite web |url=http://www.standards.dfes.gov.uk/specialistschools/ |title=Specialist Schools |work=The Standards Site |publisher=[[Department for Children, Schools and Families]] |accessdate=15 December 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218220436/http://www.standards.dfes.gov.uk/specialistschools/ |archivedate=18 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> However, this requirement was removed in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Specialist schools programme: Michael Gove announces changes|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/specialist-schools-programme-michael-gove-announces-changes|work=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503185028/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/specialist-schools-programme-michael-gove-announces-changes|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
By May 2010 there were 203 Sponsored Academies in England.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/education/10161371.stm |title=Q&A: Academies and free schools |newspaper=BBC News |date=26 May 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529074130/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/education/10161371.stm |archivedate=29 May 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Converter academies=== {{anchor|Converter Academy}} The [[Academies Act 2010]] sought to increase the number of academies. It enabled all maintained schools to convert to academy status, known as '''Converter Academies''' and enabled new academies to be created via the [[Free school (England)|Free School Programme]].
At the same time the new Conservative-led Coalition Government announced that they would redirect funding for school Specialisms [i.e. Technology College Status] into mainstream funding.<ref name=SpecialismChanges>{{cite web|title=Specialist schools programme: Michael Gove announces changes|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/specialist-schools-programme-michael-gove-announces-changes|work=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=4 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503185028/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/specialist-schools-programme-michael-gove-announces-changes|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This meant that Secondary Schools would no longer directly receive ring-fenced funds of c£130K from Government for each of their specialisms.<ref name=EveStandSpecialisms>{{cite news|last=Waugh|first=Paul|title=Michael Gove signals end for specialist schools|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/michael-gove-signals-end-for-specialist-schools-6527122.html|accessdate=4 May 2014|newspaper=Evening Standard|date=19 Oct 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504223124/http://www.standard.co.uk/news/michael-gove-signals-end-for-specialist-schools-6527122.html|archivedate=4 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> One way to regain some direct control over their finances was to become a Converter Academy and receive all of their funding direct from Government, with the possibility of buying in services at a cheaper rate.<ref name=BBCFAQ>{{cite web|title=Q&A: Academies |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-13274090 |work=BBC News website |publisher=BBC |accessdate=4 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212192613/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-13274090 |archivedate=12 February 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> This, along with some schools wanting more independence from [[local authority]] control, meant that many state secondary schools in England converted to academy status in subsequent years.<ref>"Huge increase in academies takes total to more than 2300", Dept. for Education Press Notice, Sept. 7 2012. ({{cite web|url=http://www.education.gov.uk/inthenews/inthenews/a00213703/huge-increase-in-academies-takes-total-to-more-than-2300 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405040951/http://www.education.gov.uk/inthenews/inthenews/a00213703/huge-increase-in-academies-takes-total-to-more-than-2300 |archivedate=5 April 2013 |df=dmy }})</ref>
By April 2011, the number of academies had increased to 629, and by August 2011, reached 1,070.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.education.gov.uk/schools/leadership/typesofschools/academies/a0069811/schools-submitting-applications-and-academies-that-have-opened-in-201011 |title=Open academies and academy projects in development – The Department for Education |publisher=Education.gov.uk |date=19 August 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831194526/http://www.education.gov.uk/schools/leadership/typesofschools/academies/a0069811/schools-submitting-applications-and-academies-that-have-opened-in-201011 |archivedate=31 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> By July 2012 this number reached 1,957, double that of the previous year.<ref name="education.gov.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.education.gov.uk/schools/leadership/typesofschools/academies/b00208569/open-academies |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-08-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223002024/http://www.education.gov.uk/schools/leadership/typesofschools/academies/b00208569/open-academies |archivedate=23 February 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref> and, at 1 November 2013, it stood at 3,444.<ref name="education.gov.uk"/>
There are no academies in Wales or Scotland, where education policy is devolved.
The [[Education Funding Agency]] monitors financial management and governance of academies. In March 2016 the [[Perry Beeches The Academy|Perry Beeches The Academy Trust]], a multi-academy trust, was found to have deleted financial records for £2.5 million of free school meal funding, and that the chief executive was being paid by sub-contractors as well as by the trust. Its schools are likely to be taken over by a new trust.<ref name="guardian-20160328">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/mar/28/perry-beeches-academy-chain-stripped-schools-critical-finance-report |title=Lauded academy chain to be stripped of schools after finances inquiry |author=Richard Adams |newspaper=The Guardian |date=28 March 2016 |accessdate=28 March 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160328205955/http://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/mar/28/perry-beeches-academy-chain-stripped-schools-critical-finance-report |archivedate=28 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In August 2016, the former principal and founder of [[Kings Science Academy]], the former finance director, and a former teacher who was the founder's sister were found guilty of defrauding public funds of £150,000.<ref name="bbc-20160801">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-36943526 |title=Bradford Kings Science academy staff convicted of fraud |work=BBC News |date=1 August 2016 |accessdate=1 August 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160801141259/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-36943526 |archivedate=1 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In October 2017, the [[Wakefield City Academies Trust]] collapsed, and ''[[The Observer]]'' reported that "Wakefield City Academies Trust now stands accused of 'asset stripping” after it transferred millions of pounds of the schools’ savings to its own accounts before collapsing. On 8 September it released a statement announcing it would divest itself of its 21 schools as it could not undertake the ´rapid improvement our academies need' ".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Perraudin|first1=Frances|title=Collapsing academy trust ‘asset-stripped its schools of millions’|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/oct/21/collapsing-wakefield-city-academies-trust-asset-stripped-schools-millions-say-furious-parents|accessdate=22 October 2017|work=The Observer|date=21 October 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171021233011/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/oct/21/collapsing-wakefield-city-academies-trust-asset-stripped-schools-millions-say-furious-parents|archivedate=21 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Support==
Whilst still in the fairly early stage of development, supporters pointed to emerging data showing "striking"<ref> {{cite news |last = Adonis |first = Andrew |authorlink = Andrew Adonis |title = Academies are a success story |publisher = ''[[The Guardian]]'' |date = 31 December 2009 |url = https://www.theguardian.com/education/2006/aug/25/gcses.secondaryschools |accessdate = 3 September 2008 |location = London |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140925083434/http://www.theguardian.com/education/2006/aug/25/gcses.secondaryschools |archivedate = 25 September 2014 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> improvements in [[GCSE]] results for academies compared to their predecessors,<ref name="jacqui_smith"> {{Cite news |last = Smith |first = Jacqui |author-link = Jacqui Smith |title = This is a comprehensive success story |newspaper = [[The Guardian]] |date = 15 November 2005 |accessdate = 31 December 2009 |url = https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2005/nov/15/schools.newschools |location = London |postscript = <!--None--> |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140504172525/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2005/nov/15/schools.newschools |archivedate = 4 May 2014 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> with early results showing that "GCSE results are improving twice as fast in academies as in state schools".<ref name="indie_faq" />
In an article in ''[[The Observer]]'', that regarded many of the Government's claims for academies with scepticism, journalist [[Geraldine Bedell]] conceded that:
:They seem, so far, to be working – not all as spectacularly as Mossbourne, but much better than most of the struggling inner-city schools they replaced.<ref name="bedell"> {{cite news | last = Bedell | first = Geraldine | title = Children of the revolution | publisher = ''[[The Observer]]'' | date = 31 August 2008 | accessdate =2 September 2008 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/aug/31/secondaryschools.schools | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080901151620/http://www.guardian.co.uk/education/2008/aug/31/secondaryschools.schools| archivedate= 1 September 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} </ref>
The article singles out the cited academy, [[Mossbourne Community Academy]] in [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], as "apparently the most popular [school] in Britain – at least with politicians" and "the top school in the country for value-added results".<ref name="bedell" />

=== Opposition within Labour === The introduction of academy schools was opposed, notably by teachers' trade unions and some high-profile members within the Labour Party, such as former party leader [[Neil Kinnock|Lord Kinnock]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/mar/23/schools.newschools Teachers' leader slams academy school plan] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217223303/http://www.guardian.co.uk/education/2008/mar/23/schools.newschools |date=17 February 2011 }}, ''[[The Observer]]'', 23 March 2008.</ref><ref name="Kinnock criticises city academies">{{cite news | title=Kinnock criticises city academies | date=18 April 2006 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4917808.stm | work=BBC News | accessdate=29 November 2009 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061224171954/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4917808.stm | archivedate=24 December 2006 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Neil Kinnock]] criticised the academies scheme saying that they were a "distortion of choice" and risked creating a "seller's market" with "schools selecting parents and children instead of parents selecting schools".<ref name="Kinnock criticises city academies" />
<!--Paragraph is a mess. Far too many repetitive citations -->=== Education Select Committee in 2005 === The [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] [[Education and Skills Select Committee]] reported in March 2005 that it would have been wiser to limit the programme to 30 or 50 academies in order to evaluate the results before expanding the programme, and that "the rapid expansion of the Academy policy comes at the expense of rigorous evaluation".<ref>{{cite web |author=The Committee Office, House of Commons |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200405/cmselect/cmeduski/86/8605.htm#a2 |title=House of Commons – Education and Skills – Fifth Report |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629155129/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200405/cmselect/cmeduski/86/8605.htm#a2 |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Select Committee was concerned that the promising results achieved by some academies may be due to increased exclusions of harder-to-teach pupils. They noted that two [[Middlesbrough]] academies had expelled 61 pupils, compared to just 15 from all other secondary schools in the borough.<ref name="parkinson" />
=== Criticism of choice of sponsors === The programme of creating academies has also been heavily criticised by some for handing schools to private sector entrepreneurs who in many cases have no experience of the education sector – most infamously, the Evangelical Christian car dealer, Sir [[Peter Vardy (businessman)|Peter Vardy]], who has been accused of promoting the teaching of [[creationism]] alongside [[macroevolution]] in his [[Emmanuel Schools Foundation]] academies.<ref name="bedell" /><ref name="harris" /> This is also linked to the wider debate in the education sector as to the benefits or otherwise of the growing role of religion in the school system being promoted by the New Labour government in general, and Tony Blair in particular, with many<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/3901679.stm |title=Education | Faith groups back more academies |publisher=BBC News |date=17 July 2004 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201144323/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/3901679.stm |archivedate=1 December 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hinsliff|first=Gaby|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/aug/07/schools.newschools|title=City schools could be front for evangelists|work=The Observer|date=7 August 2005|accessdate=17 November 2017|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171118222554/https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/aug/07/schools.newschools|archivedate=18 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> academies (one estimate puts it at "more than half"<ref>[http://richarddawkins.net/articles/106 "Root of All Evil? Part 2: The Virus of Faith"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100422005717/http://richarddawkins.net/articles/106 |date=22 April 2010 }} by [[Richard Dawkins]] – [[Channel 4]] – RichardDawkins.net</ref>) being sponsored either by religious groups or organisations/individuals with a religious affiliation.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/faith-schools-are-at-odds-with-reason-says-chaplain-473817.html |title=Faith schools are 'at odds with reason', says chaplain – Education News, Education |work=The Independent |date=12 April 2006 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |location=London |first=Richard |last=Garner |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206030806/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/faith-schools-are-at-odds-with-reason-says-chaplain-473817.html |archivedate=6 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Failing academies === There are indications that several city academies are failing.<ref name="hattersley"/> Ofsted has placed the [[Unity City Academy]]<ref name=UnityOfsted>{{cite news | url=http://politics.guardian.co.uk/publicservices/story/0,11032,1494519,00.html | title=New-style academy condemned as failure | work=The Guardian | location=London | first=Rebecca | last=Smithers | date=28 May 2005 | accessdate=27 March 2010 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070227124520/http://politics.guardian.co.uk/publicservices/story/0,11032,1494519,00.html | archivedate=27 February 2007 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> in [[Middlesbrough]] and the [[Richard Rose Central Academy]]<ref name=RoseOfsted>{{cite web | title=Ofsted inspection report, Richard Rose Central Academy | url=http://www.richardroseacademies.org/central/images/stories/pdfs/rrca-135621-published_inspection_report.pdf | accessdate=9 February 2009 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206083502/http://www.richardroseacademies.org/central/images/stories/pdfs/rrca-135621-published_inspection_report.pdf | archivedate=6 February 2009 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> in [[Carlisle]] under [[special measures]], heavily criticised the [[West London Academy]]<ref name=WestLondon>{{cite news |author=Press Association |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2006/mar/07/schools.uk1 |title=Ofsted criticises London academy standards | Education |work=The Guardian |date=7 March 2006 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002152110/http://www.theguardian.com/education/2006/mar/07/schools.uk1 |archivedate=2 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> in [[Ealing]] and condemned standards at the [[Business Academy Bexley|Business Academy]] in [[Bexley]], Kent.<ref name=WestLondon/>
The Richard Rose Central Academy in [[Carlisle]], sponsored by Eddie Stobart owner [[Andrew Tinkler]], and local businessman Brian Scowcroft opened in September 2008. By January 2009, there were protests by parents and pupils regarding poor quality education and school facilities. The school was found to be failing<ref name=RoseOfsted/> and was placed in special measures, with the headmaster and chief executive being immediately replaced.<ref name=RosePressRelease>{{cite web | title=Richard Rose Central Academy: Press Release | url=http://www.richardroseacademies.org/central/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=75&Itemid=81 | accessdate=9 February 2009 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220085825/http://www.richardroseacademies.org/central/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=75&Itemid=81 | archivedate=20 February 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A parliamentary report in 2015, entitled "Free Schools and Academies", recommends that "In the meantime the Government should stop exaggerating the success of academies and be cautious about firm conclusions except where the evidence merits it. Academisation is not always successful nor is it the only proven alternative for a struggling school".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201415/cmselect/cmeduc/258/258.pdf|title=Archived copy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160703144354/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201415/cmselect/cmeduc/258/258.pdf|archivedate=3 July 2016|deadurl=no|accessdate=2015-05-08|df=dmy}}</ref> In 2016 a major study by the [[Education Policy Institute]] found no significant differences in performance between Academies and local council run schools, and that multi-academy trusts running at least five schools performed worse than local council run schools. <ref name="independent-20160707">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/academy-trust-schools-among-the-worst-at-raising-pupil-performance-new-research-shows-a7124651.html|title=Academy trust schools among the worst at raising pupil performance, new research shows|author=Jon Stone|date=7 July 2016|newspaper=The Independent|accessdate=7 July 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708135821/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/academy-trust-schools-among-the-worst-at-raising-pupil-performance-new-research-shows-a7124651.html|archivedate=8 July 2016|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Expense and diversion of funding === The original '''City Academy''' programme was attacked for its expense: it cost on average £25m<ref name="parkinson"/> to build an academy under this scheme, much of which was taken up by the costs of new buildings. Critics contend that this is significantly more than it costs to build a new local authority school.<ref>{{cite web |last=Behr |first=Rafael |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200409200021 |title=How car dealers can run state schools |work=New Statesman |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606041910/http://www.newstatesman.com/200409200021 |archivedate=6 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Some [[#Operators|operators]] are paying senior staff six-figure salaries, partly funded by central government.<ref name="guardian pay gbp200k salaries">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/nov/14/academies-pay-200k-salaries |title=Academies pay £200k salaries |work=The Guardian |date=14 November 2011 |accessdate=15 November 2011 |author=Shepherd, Jessica |quote=Charities that run chains of academy schools are using public funds to pay senior staff six-figure salaries, with some on £240,000 or more. |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504205630/http://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/nov/14/academies-pay-200k-salaries |archivedate=4 May 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2012, the academy scheme was applied to primary schools. The government began transforming some schools that had been graded Satisfactory or lower by [[Ofsted]] into academies, in some cases removing existing governing bodies and Head Teachers. An example was Downhills Primary School in Haringey, where the Head resisted turning the school into an academy. Ofsted were called in to assess the school, and placed it in [[Special measures|Special Measures]]. The head and the Governing Body were removed and replaced with a Government-appointed board. There was opposition from the school and parents.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-17385311 |work=BBC News |title=Academy row school governors sacked by Michael Gove |date=15 March 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813033727/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-17385311 |archivedate=13 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haringeyindependent.co.uk/news/9592486.Protesting_parents__disgusted__with_Downhills_governors__removal/ |title=Protesting Tottenham parents 'disgusted' with Downhills Primary School governors' removal |accessdate=18 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130723074454/http://www.haringeyindependent.co.uk/news/9592486.Protesting_parents__disgusted__with_Downhills_governors__removal/ |archivedate=23 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In December 2012, the [[Public Accounts Committee (United Kingdom)|Public Accounts Committee]] of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] questioned Henry Stewart, of the Local Schools Network, and Rachel Wolf, of the [[New Schools Network]], on accountability and funding of academies and free schools. The Committee was review a report by the Auditor General, ''Managing the Expansion of the Academies Programme'' (HC 682), which had identified that in 2011-12 {{Currency|amount=96,000,000|Amount=million|code=GBP}} had been diverted from supporting under-performing Local Authority schools to the academies programme, followed by a further {{Currency|amount=400,000,000|Amount=million|code=GBP}} in the financial year 2012-13.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmselect/cmpubacc/787/121203.htm|title=House of Commons - Public Accounts - No - Minutes of Evidence: HC 787|website=publications.parliament.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nao.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/010013-001-Academies-programme_with-correction-slip.pdf|title=Managing the expansion of the Academies Programme (HC 682)|last=Morse|first=Amyas|date=20 November 2012|year=2012|website=www.nao.org.uk|publisher=National Audit Office|type=PDF|isbn=978-0-10-298047-9|id=HC 682|access-date=2018-05-03}}</ref> The Committee also questioned [[Chris Wormald]], then [[Permanent Secretary]] at the [[Department for Education]], who admitted that the Government had deliberately chosen to remove money originally allocated to support under performing schools. Chris Wormald stated, "The Government took a very conscious decision that its major school improvement programme was the academies programme."<ref name=":0" />
==Party policies, and developments since the end of the Labour Government==
The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] has supported the academy proposal from its inception but wants the scheme to go further.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/4236354.stm |title=Education | Parents back academies says Blair |publisher=BBC News |date=12 September 2005 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016113927/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/4236354.stm |archivedate=16 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> This accord was reflected in a remark made by Conservative spokesman [[David Willetts]] in 2006:
{{quote|I am more authentically Andrew Adonis than Andrew Adonis is.|[[David Willetts]]|<ref>{{cite news |last=Baker |first=Mike |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/4996946.stm |title=Education | Blair's legacy for schools |publisher=BBC News |date=19 May 2006 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061231222205/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/4996946.stm |archivedate=31 December 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>}}
In 2004, the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] were reported as being "split" on the issue and so decided that academies should not be mentioned in the party's education policy.<ref name="libdem_2004">{{cite news |author=Hélène Mulholland in Bournemouth |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2004/sep/21/libdems2004.liberaldemocrats3 |title=Lib Dems split over city academies | Politics |work=The Guardian |date=21 September 2004 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140916204008/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2004/sep/21/libdems2004.liberaldemocrats3 |archivedate=16 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The position of [[Phil Willis]], the education spokesman at the time, was summarised as:
{{quote|… there [are] no plans to abolish either city academies or specialist schools if the Lib Dems came to power, though "they would be brought under local authority control".|[[Phil Willis]]|<ref name="libdem_2004" />}}
In 2005, Willis' successor, [[Ed Davey]], argued that academies were creating a "two-tier education system"<ref name="davey">{{cite news |author=Matthew Taylor, education correspondent |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2005/oct/31/uk.newschools |title=City academies accused of deserting poor | Politics |work=The Guardian |date=31 October 2005 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140920022711/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2005/oct/31/uk.newschools |archivedate=20 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and called for the academy programme to be halted until "a proper analysis can be done".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/doubts-grow-over-city-academies-492357.html |title=Doubts grow over city academies – Education News, Education |work=The Independent |date=28 May 2005 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090904161405/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/doubts-grow-over-city-academies-492357.html |archivedate=4 September 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> At the subsequent election, Academies were supported by all three main political parties,<ref>{{cite news |author=Polly Curtis, education editor |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/aug/30/newschools.gcses |title=As 51 academy schools prepare for first day, GCSEs show work still to be done | Education |work=The Guardian |date=30 August 2008 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715090154/http://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/aug/30/newschools.gcses |archivedate=15 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> with a further cross-party initiative to extend the programme into primary schools currently being considered.<ref>{{cite news |author=Polly Curtis, education editor |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/jul/16/schools.newschools |title=Education: Expand academy model into primary sector, says thinktank | Education |work=The Guardian In 2010 the [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|Conservatives and Liberal Democrats coalition government]] announced plans to expand the academy programme with the [[Academies Act 2010]]. ==Comparisons== The city academy programme was originally based on the programme of [[City Technology College]]s (CTCs) created by the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] government under [[Margaret Thatcher]] in the 1980s, which were also business-sponsored.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
From 2003, the Government encouraged CTCs to convert to academies; did so (for example, Djanogly CTC is now [[Djanogly City Academy]]) was a 2003 conversion.
Academies differ from CTCs in several ways; most notably, academies cannot select more than 10% of pupils by ability {{Citation needed|date=July 2016}}, whereas CTCs can.
Academies have been compared to US [[charter school]]s,<ref name="smithers">Rebecca Smithers, ''[[The Guardian]]'', 6 July 2005, [http://education.guardian.co.uk/schools/story/0,5500,1522109,00.html "Hedge fund charity plans city academies"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060202165655/http://education.guardian.co.uk/schools/story/0%2C5500%2C1522109%2C00.html |date=2 February 2006 }}</ref> which are publicly funded schools largely independent of state and federal control.
=={{visible anchor|Multi-academy trust}}s== {{anchor|operator}} A number of private and charitable organisations run groups of academies. These major operators include [[Absolute Return for Kids|ARK Schools]], [[Academies Enterprise Trust]], [[E-ACT]] (formerly Edutrust Academies Charitable Trust), [[Emmanuel Schools Foundation]], [[Harris Federation]], [[Oasis Trust]], [[Ormiston Academies Trust]], [[Tauheedul Education Trust]] and [[United Learning Trust]].
The Department for Education publishes a full list of active academy sponsors.<ref name=sponsorLists>{{cite web|title=Academy sponsor contact list|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/academy-sponsor-contact-list|work=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=4 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504022100/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/academy-sponsor-contact-list|archivedate=4 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In September 2017, the [[Wakefield City Academies Trust]] announced it was winding down and ceasing to trade as it hadn't the capacity to manage its 21 schools and asked the government to make an alternative arrangement.<ref name="Failing">{{cite news|last1=Press Association|title=Failing academy trust to pull out of 21 schools|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/sep/09/failing-academy-trust-to-pull-out-of-21-schools|accessdate=9 September 2017|work=The Guardian|agency=Press Association|date=9 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909090704/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/sep/09/failing-academy-trust-to-pull-out-of-21-schools|archivedate=9 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In January 2018, concern was expressed that MATs were not always delivering the results that the government had hoped for. A league table was produced to name and shame the worst performers using the [[Progress 8 benchmark]], which measures GCSE results after compensating for each pupil's performance at the end of [[Key Stage 2]].<ref name="tesJan2018">{{cite news|last1=George|first1=Martin|title=League tables: Best and worst performing multi-academy trusts revealed|url=https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-news/league-tables-best-and-worst-performing-multi-academy-trusts-revealed|accessdate=29 January 2018|work=Tes|date=25 January 2018|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180130151028/https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-news/league-tables-best-and-worst-performing-multi-academy-trusts-revealed|archivedate=30 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

It is not just academically where multi-academy trusts are failing. They fail in staff remuneration, being exempt from all Teacher Pay and Conditions agreements. In March 2018, the Guardian revealed that they fail in gender equality.<ref name="DuncanAdams">{{cite news|last1=Adams|first1=Richard|last2=Duncan|first2=Pamela|title=Gender pay gaps in academy school chains among the worst in UK|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/25/gender-pay-gaps-in-academy-school-chains-among-the-worst-in-uk|accessdate=25 March 2018|work=the Guardian|date=25 March 2018|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180325144440/https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/25/gender-pay-gaps-in-academy-school-chains-among-the-worst-in-uk|archivedate=25 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The study reveals several trusts where women face hourly pay deficit of more than 50%. The worst offender is [[Schoolsworks Academy Trust]], [[West Sussex]] where the median hourly pay gap in favour of men is 62% – meaning that a woman is paid 38 pence for every £1 earned by a man. The [[Wakefield City Academies Trust]], which managed 21 schools before its collapse, had a median hourly gender pay gap of 52%. The [[Kent Catholic Schools Partnership]] staff face a gender pay gap of almost 50%.<ref name="DuncanAdams" />

{{Unreferenced|date=July 2007}} '''Alexey Vasilyevich Peshekhonov''' ({{lang-ru|Алексе́й Васи́льевич Пешехо́нов}}) (February 2, 1867 (January 21 [[Old Style and New Style dates|old style]]) – April 3, 1933) was a [[Russia]]n economist, publicist, and statistician. He was a member of the Russian [[Russian Provisional Government|provisional government]] as a minister of food supplies for some months in the summer of 1917.
== Life == [[File:Alexey Vasilyevich Peshekhonov.jpg|thumb|right|Alexey Peshekhonov]] Peshekhonov was a self-educated social activist. Enrolled early in a Tver seminary for priests, he was expelled for political activity at age 17 (in 1884), and seems to have had no further formal training. He was strongly influenced by the ''[[narodnik]]'' philosopher [[Nikolay Mikhaylovsky|N.K. Mikhailovsky.]] After military service 1888 to 1891, he worked first as a village teacher and later as a statistician for the Tver and Orla zemstvo councils, then the Kaluga province zemstvo administration where he became head of the statistical service (1896-1898). During this period he published noted studies on rural life that earned him entry into employment as a journalist in St. Petersburg (1899). He was also during this period several times arrested for his political activities, imprisoned or banished from his place of residence.
Around the turn of the century, in addition to his journalism, Peshekhonov became increasingly active in the left-liberal political world - i.e., he was co-founder in 1903 of a "[[Constitutional Democratic Party|Union for Liberation]]" (Soiuz osvobozhdeniia). He was also briefly a member of the [[Socialist-Revolutionary Party]] but objected to its use of terror. In 1906, he co-founded, with [[Nikolai Annensky|N.F. Annensky]], [[Venedikt Miakotin|V.A. Miakotin]] and others, the [[Popular Socialists (Russia)|Popular Socialist Party]] (NSP). After the "Bloody Sunday" events of January 1905, he was locked up in the Peter and Paul Fortress, then banished until October of that year, and again arrested for several months in 1906. During the following years, Peshekhonov published several books on agrarian, economic and political issues.
In February 1917 Peshekhonov assumed leading roles as an NS delegate in the Petrograd Soviet of Worker's and Soldier's Deputies, with strong engagement on agrarian issues. He favoured co-operation of the Soviet with the (Kadet) Provisional Government, and in May 1917 joined the coalition government then formed as minister of food supplies. In October, he was deputy chairman of the pre-parliament council, and after the [[Bolshevik]] seizure of power joined the left-center opposition. In 1921 he played a leading role in organising famine relief for Russia.
In the fall of 1922, Peshekhonov was included in the list of intellectuals to be exiled abroad by a Central Committee decree (although he does not seem to have travelled on the famous "[[Philosophers' ships]]" that took the bulk of them to Germany). Exiled against his will, more left-wing than most of his co-expellees, Peshekhonov unhappily pursued his economic and political studies in Berlin and Prague, but repeatedly applied for permission to return to the Soviet Union. This was never granted, but eventually he was given a post as a consultant to the Soviet Trade Mission in [[Riga]], where he died in 1933. His remains were permitted to return and buried in Leningrad.
== References == * [http://www.hrono.ru/biograf/peshehonov.html Biography (in Russian)] * [http://www.biografija.ru/show_bio.aspx?id=105977 Biography (in Russian)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071121062835/http://www.millionreferatov.ru/text/59/591.htm Biography (in Russian)] * [[:ru:Пешехонов, Алексей Васильевич|Biographical entry (Russian Wikipedia)]] * Lesley Chamberlain, ''The Philosophy Steamer: Lenin and the Exile of the Intelligentsia'', London: Atlantic Books, 2006, ''passim''.
