{{Infobox Ambassador |name = Amos Hochstein |image = Amos Hochstein 2014.jpg |office = Special Envoy and Coordinator for International Energy Affairs |president = [[Barack Obama]] |predecessor = [[Carlos Pascual (diplomat)|Carlos Pascual]] |term_start = August 1, 2014 |term_end = January 20, 2017 |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |birth_place = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|1|4}} |death_place = |death_date = |nationality = [[United States]] |children = 4 }} '''Amos J. Hochstein'''<ref name="State">{{cite web|title=Amos J Hochstein|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/biog/230679.htm|publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]]|date=August 1, 2014|accessdate=April 2, 2016}}</ref> (born January 4, 1973) is a U.S. businessman, former diplomat, lobbyist, and national security and energy expert. He has worked in the U.S. Congress, has testified before congressional panels<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://docs.house.gov/meetings/FA/FA13/20140611/102323/HHRG-113-FA13-Wstate-HochsteinA-20140611.pdf|title=Assessing Energy Priorities in the Middle East and North Africa|last=|first=|date=2014-06-11|website=House Foreign Affairs Committee|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref> and has served under the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Barack Obama administration]] under [[United States Secretary of State|Secretaries of State]] [[Hillary Clinton|Clinton]] and [[John Kerry|Kerry]]. He was appointed Deputy Assistant Secretary of State in 2011 and as Special Envoy and Coordinator for International Energy Affairs. In 2015, [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]] nominated Hochstein to be the [[Assistant Secretary of State for Energy Resources|Assistant Secretary of State for Energy Ressources]].
While at the [[United States Department of State|State Department]], Hochstein worked as a close advisor to [[Vice President of the United States|Vice-President]] [[Joe Biden]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sYYrDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT159&lpg=PT159&dq=%22Amos+Hochstein%22+%22Joe+Biden%22+%22Promise+me+Dad%22&source=bl&ots=S18Pv7k7-T&sig=IsdQfEkKZFTJRtGMZxXK2Y02KzA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjb6O_Cr6vdAhVk9YMKHYCWAZwQ6AEwAHoECAAQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Amos%20Hochstein%22%20%22Joe%20Biden%22%20%22Promise%20me%20Dad%22&f=false|title=Promise Me, Dad: A Year of Hope, Hardship, and Purpose|last=Biden|first=Joe|date=2017-11-14|publisher=Flatiron Books|isbn=9781250171689|language=en}}</ref> He served in the administration from 2011 to 2017.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Kerry Officially Appoints Amos Hochstein as Energy Envoy. Oh, Hey, What’s That?|url=http://diplopundit.net/2014/12/09/kerry-officially-appoints-amos-hochstein-as-energy-envoy-oh-hey-whats-that/|work=Diplopundit|date=December 9, 2014 |accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref>
In March 2017, he joined [[Tellurian Inc|Tellurian]], a private [[Houston]]-based [[Liquefied natural gas|LNG]] company, where he serves as Senior Vice President Marketing. He serves on the supervisory board of [[Naftogaz]] as well as the Board's of the [[Atlantic Council]] and [[U.S.-India Business Council]].
==Career==
===Advising Congress=== Hochstein began his career in [[Washington, D.C.]] on [[Capitol Hill]] where he first served on the [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|U.S. House Committee on Foreign Affairs]] staff.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://docs.house.gov/meetings/FA/FA13/20140611/102323/HHRG-113-FA13-Wstate-HochsteinA-20140611.pdf|title=Assessing Energy Priorities in the Middle East and North Africa|last=|first=|date=2011-06-11|website=U.S. House of Representatives|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> In subsequent years he served in a variety of senior level positions, including the [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|House International Relations Committee]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1999/07/19/on-a-grim-weekend-a-note-of-hope/9b54a0a2-b590-4de3-88ac-6aca1b091b7e/|title=On a Grim Weekend, A Note of Hope|last=Wax|first=Roxanne Roberts; Emily|date=1999-07-19|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> where he served as Senior Policy Advisor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2015/10/08/president-obama-announces-more-key-administration-posts|title=President Obama Announces More Key Administration Posts|date=2015-10-08|work=whitehouse.gov|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en}}</ref> In 1997 he later was sent to [[North Korea]] to report on the country's economic and military status as well as the progress and opportunities for humanitarian relief efforts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?91427-1/north-korea-hunger-problem&start=11898|title=North Korea Hunger Problem|website=C-SPAN.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref>
Later, Hochstein served as the Senior Policy Advisor to the [[House Foreign Affairs Committee|Foreign Affairs Committee]] of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]]. Hochstein first served as the principal Democratic staff person on the [[Economic Policy, Trade & Environment Subcommittee]] where he oversaw work authorizing [[Ex-Im Bank]], [[Overseas Private Investment Corporation|OPIC]] and [[USTDA]], as well as drafting legislation on export controls and trade-related multilateral organizations and regimes.
Hochstein also worked as a Senior Policy Advisor to then-Governor [[Mark Warner]], and later as Policy Director for Senator [[Chris Dodd]].<ref name="State" /> He joined Dodd's team in the beginning of 2007 and was the Policy Director during his [[Chris Dodd presidential campaign, 2008|2008 Presidential campaign]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/thefix/inner-circle/dodd-inner-circle.html|title=Chris Dodd's Kitchen Cabinet|last=|first=|date=|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2008/candidates/chris.dodd.html|title=Election Center 2008: Candidates - Election & Politics News from CNN.com|website=www.cnn.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref>
Hochstein was also an aide to Representative [[Sam Gejdenson]].<ref name="WaPo" />
===Cassidy & Associates=== Hochstein later moved to the [[private sector]] as Executive Vice President of International Operations at Cassidy & Associates.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://assets.aeaweb.org/assets/production/articles-attachments/aer/app/10412/20121147_app.pdf|title=Is It Whom You Know or What You Know?|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-07}}</ref> Throughout his career, he was a counselor and lobbyist for both domestic and international oil and gas companies, as well as companies focusing on renewable energy. In this capacity, he assisted corporations in assessing potential new markets and the development of alternative sources of power.<ref name="State"/>
While working at Cassidy & Associates, Hochstein also worked on the account of the President of Equatorial Guinea, [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema]], Africa's longest serving dictator,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2012/02/09/the-five-worst-leaders-in-africa/#19a1b7155516|title=The Five Worst Leaders In Africa|last=Nsehe|first=Mfonobong|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en}}</ref> to improve the relationship with the United States. In his book "Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power", two times [[Pulitzer Prize]] winner [[Steve Coll]] recounts, that while Hochstein initially was uncomfortable with the Equatorial Guinea account,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pbOKDQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Private+Empire:+ExxonMobil+and+American+Power&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiDuI6025rdAhURWqwKHdO3DrQQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=Hochstein&f=false|title=Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power|last=Coll|first=Steve|date=2012-05-01|publisher=Penguin|year=|isbn=9781101572146|location=|pages=292|language=en}}</ref> he assisted in the development of a "road map" of political changes together with the [[United States National Security Council|U.S. National Security Council]], that Equatorial Guinea would have to implement in order to display their political sincerity to change and to improve relations with the United States. The outlines involved prisoner releases, substantial public investments in health care and education and Hochstein coordinated the communication of these points with and between Equatorial Guinea's leadership and the State Department.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pbOKDQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Private+Empire:+ExxonMobil+and+American+Power&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiDuI6025rdAhURWqwKHdO3DrQQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=Hochstein&f=false|title=Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power|last=Coll|first=Steve|date=2012-05-01|publisher=Penguin|year=|isbn=9781101572146|location=|pages=295|language=en}}</ref> Hochstein and others, among them Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] and [[Paul Wolfowitz]], said they were convinced by Obiang's will to change and adapt. Equatorial Guinea under the Obiang regime remains by many accounts one of the world's least free countries.<ref>https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world-2018-table-country-scores</ref> Hochstein defended the Obiang regime in an interview with the [[The Washington Post|Washington Post]].<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/21/AR2006042101754.html</ref> He stated that the development and support of the democratic process in countries like Equatorial Guinea must be supported and that Western states cannot expect changes of long-standing political realities overnight.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/21/AR2006042101754.html|title=A CONVERSATION WITH AMOS HOCHSTEIN Interview by michael grunwald|date=2006-04-23|access-date=2018-09-01|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/amos-j-hochstein/guinea-a-triumph-for-afri_b_656202.html|title=Guinea: A Triumph for African Democracy|last=Hochstein|first=Amos J.|last2=Clack|first2=Mark C.|date=2010-07-22|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-01}}</ref> Eventually Hochstein resigned from the lobbying account but continued to work for Cassidy until 2006.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pbOKDQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Private+Empire:+ExxonMobil+and+American+Power&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiDuI6025rdAhURWqwKHdO3DrQQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=Hochstein&f=false|title=Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power|last=Coll|first=Steve|date=2012-05-01|publisher=Penguin|year=|isbn=9781101572146|location=|pages=297|language=en}}</ref>
===Energy diplomat for the Obama Administration=== Hochstein began working at the [[U.S. Department of State]] in 2011, joining the newly formed [[Bureau of Energy Resources]].<ref name="DeSmogBlog">{{cite web|title=New Obama State Dept Top Energy Diplomat Amos Hochstein A Former Marathon Oil Lobbyist|url=http://www.desmogblog.com/2014/12/08/new-obama-state-department-top-energy-diplomat-formerly-marathon-oil-lobbyist|publisher=[[DeSmogBlog]]|date=December 8, 2014|accessdate=April 2, 2016}}</ref> Serving as deputy to Special Envoy [[Carlos Pascual (diplomat)|Carlos Pascual]], Hochstein worked to help [[Ukraine]] find new supplies of [[natural gas]] in the wake of the [[Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)|2014 Russian invasion]].<ref name="Reuters"/>
He oversaw the Office of Middle East, Asia and Europe, the Western Hemisphere and Africa. Hochstein led the energy related diplomacy efforts.<ref name=":0" />
==== Special Envoy and Coordinator of International Energy Affairs ==== On August 1, 2014, Hochstein succeeded [[Carlos Pascual (diplomat)|Carlos Pascual]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/steve-horn/new-obama-state-dept-top_b_6290298.html|title=New Obama State Dept Top Energy Diplomat Amos Hochstein a Former Marathon Oil Lobbyist|last=Horn|first=Steve|date=2014-12-08|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-07}}</ref> as acting Special Envoy and Coordinator of International Energy Affairs, and was permanently appointed to the position later in the year<ref name="Reuters">{{cite web|title=U.S. appoints top diplomat for energy issues|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-energy-diplomat-idUSKCN0JH2CC20141203|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=December 3, 2014|accessdate=April 2, 2016}}</ref> by Secretary Kerry.<ref name=":0" /> As the Special Envoy, Hochstein oversaw the Bureau of Energy Resources and advised [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[John Kerry]] on global energy security and diplomacy, as well as integration of renewable and clean energy and related security matters. He also worked closely with officials at the White House's National Security Council and other government agencies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-energy-diplomat/u-s-appoints-top-diplomat-for-energy-issues-idUSKCN0JH2CC20141203|title=U.S. appoints top diplomat for energy issues|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-07-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
In his capacity as the U.S.'s Chief Energy Diplomat, Hochstein had an important role in shaping foreign energy and security policy<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/ei/biog/230679.htm|title=Hochstein, Amos J|work=U.S. Department of State|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref> and worked closely with<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/statephotos/16187899289|title=Vice President Biden Chats With Special Envoy Hochstein at the Caribbean Energy Security Summit|work=Flickr|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-us}}</ref> U.S. Vice President [[Joe Biden]], accompanying him on international travel and advancing energy as a key US foreign policy tool. Hochstein and Biden worked together on the Caribbean Energy Security Initiative, Central America Energy Security Task Force, Cyprus and East Mediterranean, as well as securing Ukraine and Europe from Russian energy dominance.
Hochstein encouraged European countries to find new oil, gas, coal, and nuclear sources, to alleviate their dependence on [[Russia in the European energy sector|Russian energy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S., Russia at odds over energy in Cold War-style conflict|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/feb/4/us-russia-odds-over-energy-cold-war-style-conflict/|work=[[Washington Times]]|date=February 4, 2015|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref> In response to President [[Vladimir Putin]]'s plans for new gas pipelines to bypass an existing transit coordinator through [[Ukraine]] towards [[Greece]] and [[Italy]], Hochstein described the plans as "political projects that have questionable economic value" to the European energy market.<ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite web|last=Agayev|first=Zulfugar|title=U.S. Says Putin's Plans for New Gas Links are Politically Motivated|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-01/u-s-says-putin-s-plans-for-new-gas-links-are-politically-driven|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=March 1, 2016|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref> He has also stated that the U.S.'s position isn't to exclude Russia from the European market entirely, but rather that Russia should be an equal player, remarking that "European countries should be able to choose their supplier and force their suppliers to compete for their business. That is what is good for energy security of Europe, economic security and ultimately for the national security of those countries involved."<ref name="Bloomberg"/><ref>{{cite web|title=A Transatlantic Talk with Special Envoy Amos Hochstein: Energy Security – A Transatlantic Dimension|url=http://www.gmfus.org/events/transatlantic-talk-special-envoy-amos-hochstein-energy-security-%E2%80%93-transatlantic-dimension|publisher=[[German Marshall Fund]]|date=May 27, 2015|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref>
Hochstein has also been involved in the U.S. front against the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]], specifically cutting their oil revenues by disrupting their production lines.<ref>{{cite web|last=Solomon|first=Jay|title=ISIS’s Oil Revenue Is Falling, Administration Says|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2014/12/15/isiss-oil-revenue-is-falling-administration-says/|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=December 15, 2014|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref> Hochstein oversaw the U.S. efforts to cripple Islamic State's energy business by weakening oil trade between ISIS, the Syrian government and other parties.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/islamic-state-steps-up-oil-and-gas-sales-to-assad-regime-1484835563|title=Islamic State Steps Up Oil and Gas Sales to Assad Regime|last=Faucon|first=Benoit|date=2017-01-19|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-07-08|last2=Omran|first2=Ahmed Al|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> His team coordinated with the [[U.S. Department of Defense]] to determine targets.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gardner|first=Timothy|title=U.S. bombing wider Islamic State oil supply chain -Obama nominee|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/mideast-crisis-oil-usa-idUSL1N13Q32X20151201|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=December 1, 2015|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref> Airstrikes subsequently blew up over 1,000 tanker trucks and other key targets.<ref>{{cite web|last=Van Heuvelen|first=Ben|title=Armed with intel, U.S. strikes curtail IS oil sector|url=http://www.iraqoilreport.com/news/armed-intel-u-s-strikes-curtail-oil-sector-17473/|date=December 28, 2015|publisher=Iraq Oil Report|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/10/26/blowing-up-the-islamic-states-oil-company-isis-abu-sayyaf/|title=Blowing Up the Islamic State’s Oil Company|website=Foreign Policy|language=en|access-date=2018-07-08}}</ref> In a testimony before the [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]], Hochstein described the military actions as "not only more bombings, but a different kind of bombing."<ref name="Reuters"/>
Hochstein’s energy diplomacy efforts in the Middle East have been critical.<ref>Secretary John Kerry</ref> Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] cited Hochstein’s work as helping to provide an incentive for the renewed relationship between Israel and Turkey.<ref>http://www.newsroomamerica.com/story/581512.html</ref> This followed his work to revive efforts to settle maritime border dispute between Lebanon and Israel.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mesp.me/2015/07/03/amos-hochsteins-visit-to-beirut-reviving-u-s-mediation-efforts/|title=Amos Hochstein’s visit to Beirut: Reviving U.S. mediation efforts|date=2015-07-03|work=Middle East Strategic Perspectives|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}}</ref> At the conclusion of his visit, Hochstein made statements stressing his visit was to discuss delayed gas exploration in Lebanon.<ref>http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/07/lebanon-gas-exploration-bassil-hoff-hochstein.html</ref> The previous year, 2014, Hochstein helped “pave the way” for the $500 million natural gas agreement between Israel and Jordan<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israel-jordan-sign-500-million-natural-gas-deal/|title=Israel-Jordan sign $500 million natural gas deal|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}}</ref> visiting Jordan 14 times and was, alongside Israel’s former President [[Shimon Peres]], a "key broker" for the gas export deal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/israel-jordan-sign-500-million-natural-gas-deal/|title=Israel-Jordan sign $500 million natural gas deal|access-date=2018-07-15|language=en-US}}</ref> This agreement concluded an effort that Secretary of State Clinton began in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/15/business/energy-environment/israels-natural-gas-supply-offers-lifeline-for-peace.html?_r=0|title=Israel’s Gas Offers Lifeline for Peace|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en}}</ref>
In response to Russian officials claiming that the [[Turkish government]] was illegally buying oil from the Islamic State, Hochstein dismissed these claims, saying that "I do not believe there is significant smuggling between ISIL-controlled areas and Turkey of oil of any significant volume."<ref>{{cite web|last=Dockins|first=Pamela|title=US Official Rejects Russian Assertion of IS Oil Sales to Turkey|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/united-states-official-rejects-russian-assertion-islamic-state-oil-sales-turkey/3088350.html|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=December 4, 2015|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref>
Hochstein has also worked on multilateral energy affairs, meeting with [[Urban Rusnák]], Secretary-General of the [[Energy Charter Conference]], to discuss progress on the Energy Charter Process,<ref>{{cite web|title=Secretary General meets with Amos Hochstein of the US State Department|url=http://www.energycharter.org/media/news/article/secretary-general-meets-with-amos-hochstein-of-the-us-state-department|publisher=[[Energy Charter Conference]]|date=November 19, 2015|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref> discussing the advance of clean energy investments and energy security with government officials in [[India]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2016/02/252518.htm|title=Special Envoy and Coordinator for International Energy Affairs Amos J. Hochstein Travels to India To Discuss Clean Energy Investment and Energy Security|work=U.S. Department of State|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref> and meeting several other state leaders and government officials to coordinate energy and security matters with states like [[Azerbaijan]] and Saudi Arabia and other states in the Middle East.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://photos.state.gov/libraries/azerbaijan/749085/transcripts_001/baku-161216-Hochstein-Press.pdf|title=Amos Hochstein - Special Envoy and Coordinator for International Enegery Affairs|last=|first=|date=2016-12-16|website=USEmbassy.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.arabianow.org/u-s-envoy-amos-hochstein-impressed-saudi-commitment-renewable-energy/|title=U.S. Envoy Amos Hochstein Impressed by Saudi Commitment to Renewable Energy - ArabiaNow|last=ArabiaNow|date=2016-05-26|work=ArabiaNow|access-date=2018-07-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
==== Assistant Secretary of State for Energy Ressources ==== On October 8, 2015, President [[Barack Obama]] nominated Hochstein to be the [[Assistant Secretary of State for Energy Resources]], the official chief position for the bureau.<ref>{{cite web|title=President Obama Announces More Key Administration Posts|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/10/08/president-obama-announces-more-key-administration-posts|publisher=[[White House]]|date=October 8, 2015|accessdate=April 2, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PN909 — Amos J. Hochstein — Department of State|url=https://www.congress.gov/nomination/114th-congress/909|publisher=[[United States Congress]]|date=October 8, 2015|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref> Hochstein continued his efforts in all previously engaged fields of national and international energy and security matters,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/state-department-names-new-energy-envoy-1406299086|title=State Department Names Acting Energy Envoy|last=Harder|first=Amy|date=2014-07-25|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-08-11|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> including Iran sanctions,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/as-crude-oil-prices-plunge-so-do-oil-exporters-revenue-hopes/2015/12/23/ed552372-a900-11e5-8058-480b572b4aae_story.html|title=Obama’s foreign policy goals get a boost from plunging oil prices|last=|first=|date=|website=Washington Post|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/13/business/energy-environment/with-a-natural-gas-byproduct-iran-sidesteps-oil-sanctions.html|title=With Natural Gas Byproduct, Iran Sidesteps Sanctions|access-date=2018-08-11|language=en}}</ref> energy opportunities in [[Latin America]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2016/04/255437.htm|title=Special Envoy for International Energy Affairs Amos J Hochstein Travel to New York City|work=U.S. Department of State|access-date=2018-08-11}}</ref> the US-India energy cooperation,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/energy-and-environment/%E2%80%98India-U.S.-clean-energy-cooperation-will-go-on%E2%80%99/article16660410.ece|title=‘India-U.S. clean energy cooperation will go on’|date=2016-11-20|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-08-11|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> the US-[[China]] energy cooperation, the administration’s strategy on Russia,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/nord-stream-2-pipeline-spat-to-test-eu-commitment-1450298291|title=Nord Stream 2 Pipeline Spat to Test EU Commitment|last=Steinhauser|first=Gabriele|date=2015-12-16|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-08-11|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> and the fight against ISIS.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/ei/biog/230679.htm|title=Hochstein, Amos J|work=U.S. Department of State|access-date=2018-08-11}}</ref>
He also was involved in discussing and mapping out details of the [[Southern Gas Corridor]] project generally<ref name=":1" /> and the [[Trans Adriatic Pipeline]] with [[Greece]] specifically.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/09/business/international/greece-us-russia-energy-pipeline.html|title=U.S. Urges Greece to Reject Russian Energy Project|last=|first=|date=|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref>
He authored the White House Caribbean Energy Security Initiative and chaired President Obama's U.S.-Caribbean and U.S.-Central America Energy Security Task Force. He also continued to lead U.S. efforts to promote global fuel switching to [[natural gas]] and develop stronger natural gas markets in Asia and South Asia.<ref name=":1" /> He headed the State Department's Unconventional Gas Technical Engagement Program, formerly known as Global [[Shale gas|Shale Gas]] Initiative.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/steve-horn/new-obama-state-dept-top_b_6290298.html|title=New Obama State Dept Top Energy Diplomat Amos Hochstein a Former Marathon Oil Lobbyist|last=Horn|first=Steve|date=2014-12-08|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-24}}</ref>
He was succeeded by [[Francis R. Fannon|Frank R. Fannon]], now Assistant Secretary of State for Energy Resources.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://diplopundit.net/2018/02/01/oil-executive-francis-r-fannon-to-be-asst-secretary-for-the-bureau-of-energy-resources/|title=Oil Executive Francis R. Fannon to be Asst Secretary For the Bureau of Energy Resources|date=2018-02-01|work=Diplopundit|access-date=2018-08-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
Since leaving the White House, Hochstein appeared on a Trump White House panel promoting the use of fossil fuels at the 2016 Bonn Climate Change Conference.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trump's-efforts-to-promote-coal-at-climate-summit-draws-protests|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-13/trump-s-efforts-to-promote-coal-at-climate-summit-draws-protests |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=November 13, 2017|accessdate=Feb 25, 2018}}</ref>
== Tellurian == In 2017 Hochstein joined [[Tellurian Inc|Tellurian]], a private LNG-gas company and today serves as SVP of Marketing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ir.tellurianinc.com/management-team|title=Management team|last=|first=|date=|website=Tellurian Inc.|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/new-atlanticist/is-uncertainty-over-nuclear-deal-fueling-protests-in-iran|title=Is Uncertainty Over Nuclear Deal Fueling Protests in Iran?|last=Ansley|first=Rachel|work=Atlantic Council|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-gb}}</ref>
== Positions == Hochstein sees [[Renewable energy|renewable energies]] as very important and being at the center of both the future's energy market and US energy policy. He is of the opinion, that the realistic transition into a fully renewable resourced [[energy mix]], will take some time and that the use of cleaner resources (e.g. [[Liquefied natural gas|LNG]] to replace [[heavy crude oil]]s) for this transition period is crucial to sustain economic developments and growth. Hochstein said: "Here in Washington, I think we are the last city on the planet…where we still talk about [[fossil fuel]] versus renewables as some kind of zero-sum game […] It is not one or the other. It is going to have to be both because we are going to need the baseload and we are going to need the fuels that will transition us to the future."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/columnist/2016/08/09/worlds-energy-superpower-fights-opec-obsession/88474740/|title='World's energy superpower' fights OPEC obsession|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-08-25|language=en}}</ref>
At the 2015 Renewable Energy Transition event hosted by the [[International Renewable Energy Agency]] (IRENA) and the [[Atlantic Council]]'s Global Energy Center, Hochstein stated that "unlike oil and gas, the technological advances we’re seeing in renewables are making them cheaper and better."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/new-atlanticist/renewable-energy-sector-energized|title=Renewable Sector Energized|work=Atlantic Council|access-date=2018-08-25|language=en-gb}}</ref> He further said: "U.S. [[energy security]], energy sustainability and climate objectives are mutually reinforcing. As such, we are working to promote energy efficiency, conservation and transformation of energy systems. We are encouraging market reforms, such as the elimination of fossil fuel subsidies, that can address [[World energy consumption|overall energy demand]]."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.windpowerengineering.com/business-news-projects/renewable-energy-must-be-key-component-of-u-s-energy-policy-according-to-industry-leaders/|title=Renewable energy must be key component of U.S. energy policy, according to industry leaders|work=Windpower Engineering & Development|access-date=2018-08-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
Hochstein has been interviewed by national and international media, commenting on national and international energy policy, energy security, and foreign policy'''.'''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/why-saudis-decided-not-to-prop-up-oil-1419219182|title=Why Saudis Decided Not to Prop Up Oil|last=Solomon|first=Jay|date=2014-12-22|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-09-08|last2=Said|first2=Summer|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/05/08/us-encouraging-greece-to-diversify-on-energy-sources-stick-to-non-russia.html|title=US encouraging Greece to diversify on energy sources, stick to non-Russia pipeline project|date=2015-05-08|work=Fox News|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-l-phillips/research-paper-turkey-isi_b_8808024.html|title=Research Paper: Turkey-ISIS Oil Trade|last=Phillips|first=David L.|date=2015-12-15|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gmfus.org/events/conversation-amos-hochstein-obama-administrations-legacy-and-future-european-energy-security|title=A Conversation with Amos Hochstein: The Obama Administration's Legacy and the Future of European Energy Security|date=2016-11-23|work=The German Marshall Fund of the United States|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en}}</ref>
== Memberships == Hochstein is a member of the supervisory board at [[Naftogaz]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.naftogaz.com/www/3/nakweben.nsf/0/C05E55FE9F457547C2257F9D003C672C?OpenDocument&Expand=4&|title=Supervisory board|website=www.naftogaz.com|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref> and servers on the board of the [[Atlantic Council]]<ref name=":2" /> and the [[U.S.-India Business Council|U.S.-Indian Business Council]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usibc.com/director/amos-hochstein/|title=U.S.-India Business Council|website=USIBC|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref>
==Personal life== Hochstein is married to Julie Rae Ringel. They have four children.<ref name="WaPo">{{cite web|title=A Conversation with Amos Hochstein|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/21/AR2006042101754.html|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=April 23, 2006|accessdate=April 3, 2016}}</ref>

<!-- Missing image removed: [[Image:AFSH.jpg|right|thumb|Membership card of AFSH]] --> '''Antifascist Front of Slavs in Hungary''' ([[Serbo-Croatian]]: ''Antifašistički front Slovena u Mađarskoj/Антифашистички фронт Словена у Мађарској'', [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]]: ''Magyarországi Szlávok Antifasiszta Frontja'') was organization founded on February 18, 1945 in Battonya. For General Secretary was elected [[Dragutin Nedučić]] from [[Battonya]] and for vice-president [[Stevan Nedučić]] from Csanádpalota.
After ending military administration first in March local organization of AFSH were founded in [[Bács-Kiskun County|Bács]] among Bunjevci and among [[Šokci]] in [[Hercegszántó]]. Main organizer among [[Bunjevci]] was [[Antun Karagić]].
After [[Békés]] and Bács new organizations were founded around [[Budapest]]. In August County Secretariat of AFSH was founded in [[Pécs]] and for its secretary [[Svetozar Lastić]] was elected.
In September AFSH started founding other local organizations in [[Baranya (county)|Baranya]] and Baranya-Bács Slavic Cultural association joined the Front and [[Martin Laslović]] was elected as local president.
The first big rally of AFSH was on October 28, 1945 in [[Mohács]]. On December 3, 1945 first National conference was held in Mohács and Martin Laslović was elected as president.

[[Secularism]] | homepage = [http://www.6april.org/ 6april.org] | tax_exempt = | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''April 6 Youth Movement''' ''({{lang-ar|حركة شباب 6 أبريل}})'' is an Egyptian activist group established in Spring 2008 to support the workers in [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]], an industrial town, who were planning to strike on April 6.{{Cite journal|url=https://www.wired.com/techbiz/startups/magazine/16-11/ff_facebookegypt|title=Cairo Activists Use Facebook to Rattle Regime|date=20 October 2008|first=David|last=Wolman|journal=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast Publications]]|accessdate=15 February 2008}}{{cite news|title=Parliament is burning, and the watching crowd is laughing|first=Hamida|last=Ghafour|date=25 August 2008|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |publisher=[[Martin Newland]]|url=http://www.thenational.ae/article/20080825/OPINION/235828560/1080&template=opinion |accessdate=15 February 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=15325 |work=[[Daily News Egypt]] |title=Protestors say Agrium plant is like Nazi gas chambers |first=Abdel-Rahman |last=Hussein |date=27 July 2008 |publisher=Egyptian Media Services |accessdate=15 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080807013737/http://www.dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=15325 |archivedate=7 August 2008 }}{{Cite news|work=Daily News Egypt |title=April 6 youth detainees still in custody despite release order |publisher=Egyptian Media Services |first=Sarah |last=Carr |date=July 30, 2008 |url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=15407 |accessdate=15 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009080145/http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=15407 |archivedate=9 October 2010 }}{{cite news|url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=16577 |work=Daily News Egypt |title=Emaar accused of culpability in Duweiqa rockslide |publisher=Egyptian Media Services |first=Abdel Rahman |last=Hussein |date=18 September 2008 |accessdate=15 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927094002/http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=16577 |archivedate=27 September 2008 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|title=In Focus: The Dilemma of Egypt's Liberals |first=Khalil |last=Al-Anani |date=2 September 2008 |publisher=Egyptian Media Services |work=Daily News Egypt |url=http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=16173 |accessdate=15 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080928074728/http://dailystaregypt.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=16173 |archivedate=28 September 2008 }} Activists called on participants to wear black and stay home on the day of the strike. Bloggers and citizen journalists used [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[Flickr]], blogs and other new media tools to report on the strike, alert their networks about police activity, organize legal protection and draw attention to their efforts.{{cite journal|url=http://www.arabmediasociety.com/?article=692|work=Arab Media & Society|title=Core to Commonplace: The evolution of Egypt's blogosphere|publisher=American University of Cairo|first=Courtney|last=Radsch|date=Fall 2008|accessdate=15 February 2008}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' has identified the movement as the political Facebook group in Egypt with the most dynamic debates.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/25/magazine/25bloggers-t.html |title=Revolution, Facebook-Style|first=Samantha M.|last=Shapiro|work=The New York Times|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=22 January 2009|accessdate=15 February 2008}} {{As of|January 2009}}, it had 70,000 predominantly young and educated members, most of whom had not been politically active before; their core concerns include [[free speech]], [[nepotism]] in government and the country's stagnant economy. Their discussion forum on Facebook features intense and heated discussions, and is constantly updated with new postings. The April 6 movement is using the same [[raised fist]] symbol as the [[Otpor!]] movement from [[Serbia]], that helped bring down the regime of [[Slobodan Milošević]] and whose nonviolent tactics were later used in [[Ukraine]] and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. Mohammed Adel, a leader in the April 6 movement, studied at the [[Centre for Applied Nonviolent Action and Strategies]], an organization founded by former Otpor! members. The movement was banned by an Egyptian court on 28 April 2014.{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/100015/Egypt/Politics-/We-will-not-be-silenced-April-,-after-court-order-.aspx|title=We will not be silenced: April 6, after court order banning group|date=28 April 2014|accessdate=28 April 2014|work=Ahram Online}} The [[Constitution Party (Egypt)|Constitution Party]] condemned the verdict, arguing that the charges against the movement were "false" and that the court ruling was an example of state institutions undermining and destroying the rule of law.{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/100088/Egypt/Politics-/April--court-ban-is-politicised-Egypt-groups.aspx|title=April 6 court ban is politicised: Egypt groups|date=29 April 2014|accessdate=2 May 2014|work=Ahram Online}} Hamdeen Sabahi's presidential campaign warned of the "return to a state of suppression and banning." Abdul Ghaffar Shukr, vice president of the National Council for Human Rights, has stated that the council is prepared to stand in solidarity with the April 6 Youth Movement, and will aid the movement if it requests assistance.{{cite news|url=http://thecairopost.com/news/108889/news/national-council-for-human-rights-express-solidarity-with-april-6|title=National Council for Human Rights express solidarity with April 6|date=29 April 2014|accessdate=2 May 2014|work=The Cairo Post}} [[Human Rights Watch]] condemned the ruling as "a clear violation of citizens' rights to free association, peaceful assembly, and free expression."{{cite news|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2014/04/30/banning-6-april-movement-clear-violation-citizens-rights-hrw/|title=Banning 6 April movement is a clear violation of citizens' rights: HRW|date=30 April 2014|accessdate=2 May 2014|work=Daily News Egypt}} The April 6 movement has vowed to defy the ban, as well as attempt to repeal it.{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/100124/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-April--Youth-Movement-to-appeal-ban.aspx|title=Egypt's April 6 Youth Movement to appeal ban|date=2 May 2014|accessdate=2 May 2014|work=Ahram Online}} ==Founders== * [[Ahmed Maher (youth leader)|Ahmed Maher]]{{cite news|url=http://www.aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=24109|title=Asharq Al Awsat}} was a participant in the anti-[[Mubarak]] demonstrations in [[Egypt]] in 2011.Esam Al-Amin, [http://www.counterpunch.com/amin02042011.html From Counter-Attack to Departure Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207004350/http://www.counterpunch.com/amin02042011.html |date=7 February 2011 }}, Counterpunch, 4 February 2011{{cite web|first=David|last=Wolman|url=https://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/leading-egyptian-facebook-activist-arrested-friends-say/|title=Did Egypt Detain a Top Facebook Activist?|publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=2 February 2011}} *[[Mohammed Adel (youth leader)|Mohammed Adel]] worked with Kefaya movement since 2005, and one of activist who called for general strike on 6 April 2008, and then started working with Media committee in April 6 Youth Movement, and in 2009 he was the spokesman of movement and political office member. ==Public activism and arrests== Aside from discussing the state of the nation online, members of the group have organized public rallies to free imprisoned journalists and engaged in protests concerning the [[2008–2009 Israel–Gaza conflict]]. In its official pronouncements, the group stresses that it is not a [[political party]]. Ahmed Maher, one of the founders of the group, was arrested by the Egyptian authorities in May 2008 in an attempt to shut it down.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2008/05/17/ST2008051702711.html|title=Fledgling Rebellion on Facebook Is Struck Down by Force in Egypt|author=Ellen Knickmeyer|publisher=Washington Post|date=18 May 2008|accessdate=16 February 2009}} In July 2008, Maher was again arrested, along with 14 other members of the group, and charged with "incitement against the regime". He also claimed that Egyptian state security officers threatened to rape him in custody.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2008/0730/p04s04-wome.html|title=Egypt detains Facebook activists – again|author=Liam Stack|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|date=30 July 2008|accessdate=16 February 2009}} On 6 April 2009, the group was subjected to attacks, suspected to have been orchestrated by the Egyptian government. Several websites supporting the group were hacked simultaneously, and protests in Cairo were confronted by plain clothed Egyptian policemen and numerous arrests.[http://egyptianchronicles.blogspot.com/ Egyptian Chronicles]. Egyptianchronicles.blogspot.com. Retrieved on 12 March 2011 On May 2, 2010, the movement called for demonstrations under the name of the Workers' Revolution, which was aimed at achieving the minimum wage. In August of that year, slogans spread on the walls of the streets against the legacy of former President Hosni Mubarak, Most notably "Egypt is not your father's father". On 29 January 2011, a [[WikiLeaks]] document was revealed which showed that the United States considered the movement to be "outside (the) mainstream of opposition politicians and activists" and described the goals of the movement for democracy as "unrealistic" yet still supported it in various ways, including pressing "the MFA for the release of April 6 activists".[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8289698/Egypt-protests-secret-US-document-discloses-support-for-protesters.html Egypt protests: secret US document discloses support for protesters]. Telegraph (28 January 2011). Retrieved on 12 March 2011 On 31 January 2011, the movement promoted participation of at least a million in a march on 1 February 2011.anon., [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html "Egypt protesters increase pressure: Opposition movement calls for "march of millions"] on Tuesday in a bid to topple president Hosni Mubarak." (31 January 2011) On 3 February 2011, the [[Hisham Mubarak Law Center]] which was providing meeting space for the April 6 Youth Movement as well as providing medical and legal aid to the protesters was raided by security forces who arrested Amal Sharaf and other members of April 6.{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/4d590d711a.html|title=Investigate Arrests of Activists, Journalists|publisher=[[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|UNHCR]]|date=9 February 2011}} In October 2011, the group launched a "black circle, white circle" political awareness campaign. Aiming to prevent former members of Mubarak's regime from winning seats in the post-revolution parliament, the group compiled a list of candidates with ties to the dissolved National Democratic Party or with histories of corruption, which comprised the "black circle." Meanwhile, in the "white circle," the group listed a set of qualifications and characteristics they hope to see in elected officials.{{cite web|url=http://pulitzercenter.org/reporting/egypt-cairo-protest-military-government-violence-coptic| title=Anti-Military Movement Emerges in Tahrir|publisher=[[Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting|Pulitzer Center]]}} On 29 March 2013, the Movement organized an extraordinary demonstration in front of the house of the Egyptian Minister of Interior: General [[Mohamed Ibrahim Moustafa|Mohamed Ibrahim]].{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContentP/1/68571/Egypt/Live-Updates-Tense-atmosphere-as-teargas-fired-at-.aspx| title=The April 6 five-year anniversary: How peaceful protests turned violent|publisher=[[Ahram Online]]}} The activists carried women's lingerie and a banner describing the Ministry of Interior as the "prostitute of the regime".{{cite web|url=http://twitpic.com/cf5quh| title=The April 6 Activists Carrying Women Lingerie|publisher=[[Twitter account: @Mad Darsh]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.klmty.net/2013/03/6_29.html |title=The April 6 Activists Carrying Women Lingerie in front of the Interior Minster's House |publisher=[[Kelmati "My Word" News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130401011320/http://www.klmty.net/2013/03/6_29.html |archivedate=1 April 2013 }} Three of the movement activists were arrested: Abdel Azim Fahmy (Known by Zizo), Mohamed Mustapha and Mamdouh Hassan ( Known by Abou Adam). Later on a fourth activist was arrested and detained, Sayed Mounir. April 6 Movement called for a "Rage Day" against President Mohamed Mursi on the fifth anniversary of its establishment 6th April 2013.{{cite web|url=http://en.aswatmasriya.com/news/view.aspx?id=89153389-e026-44aa-b98e-7b60170e5dd6| title="April 6" calls anti-regime protest on anniversary|publisher=[[Aswat Mariya]]}} On 10 May 2013, Ahmed Maher was arrested at Cairo Airport upon his return to Egypt from a conference in the United States with charges of inciting for protests.{{cite news|title=6 April's Ahmed Maher arrested|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/05/10/6-aprils-ahmed-maher-arrested/|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Daily News Egypt]]|date=10 May 2013}} Maher was released the day after,{{cite news|title=April 6 group leader Ahmed Maher freed in Egypt|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22494687|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[BBC News Middle East]]|date=11 May 2013}} but the incident was a turning point. On 12 May, the 6 April Youth Movement decided to join the recently launched petitions collection campaign, [[Tamarod]], calling for a vote of no-confidence in the administration of President [[Mohamed Morsi]].{{cite news|title=Egypt's 6 April joins signature drive against President Morsi|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/71279.aspx/|accessdate=29 December 2013|newspaper=[[Ahramonline]]|date=12 May 2013}} In July 2013, following the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|military coup]] against [[Mohamed Morsi|President Morsi]], members of 6 April participated in [[The Third Square]], a movement created by liberal, leftist and moderate Islamist activists who reject both [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and military rule.{{cite news|title=Between Tahrir and Rabaa: The Third Square|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.com/blog/middle-east/between-tahrir-and-rabaa-third-square|accessdate=4 August 2013|newspaper=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=29 July 2013}} Many April 6 members also played founding roles in the [[Road of the Revolution Front]], an organization dedicated to achieving the revolutionary goals of bread, freedom, and social justice.{{cite news|title=New anti-military, anti-Brotherhood front to be launched Tuesday|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/82294/Egypt/Politics-/New-antimilitary,-antiBrotherhood-front-to-be-laun.aspx|accessdate=22 March 2014|newspaper=[[Al-Ahram|ahram online]]|date=23 September 2013}} In 2013, the 6 April movement held internal elections to determine who would succeed Ahmed Maher as the organization's coordinator. The vote resulted in [[Amr Ali (youth leader)|Amr Ali]], an accountant from Menufiya who has been involved in managing the group's community and public works, becoming the movement's new coordinator.{{cite news|title=Amr Ali becomes 6 April's new coordinator|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/10/28/amr-ali-becomes-6-aprils-new-coordinator/|accessdate=15 December 2013|newspaper=[[Daily News Egypt]]|date=28 October 2013}} ==Anti-Protest law campaign & arrest of movement founders== The Egyptian interim president Adly Mansour, and regardless of the widespread critics,{{cite news|title=Rights group adds to criticism of Egypt's draft protest law|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/84106/Egypt/0/Rights-group-adds-to-criticism-of-Egypts-draft-pro.aspx|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Ahramonline]]|date=16 October 2013}} approved a new law restricting protests on 24 November 2013.{{cite news|title=Egypt Approves Law Limiting Protests|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/24/egypt-protest-law-adly-mansour-_n_4333893.html|accessdate=27 December 2013|newspaper=[[Huffingtonpost]]|date=24 November 2013}}{{cite news|title=Egypt passes law restricting protests|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/11/24/world/africa/egypt-protest-law|accessdate=27 December 2013|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=25 November 2013}} The law was nationally and internationally heavily criticized with the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights [[Navi Pillay]] urging the Egyptian government to amend it or repeal it.{{cite news|title=New anti-demonstration law in Egypt must be amended, urges UN rights chief|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=46589&Cr=Egypt&Cr1|accessdate=27 December 2013|newspaper=[[UN News Centre]]|date=26 November 2013}} UN Secretary General [[Ban Ki-moon]] added his voice to those criticizing the law for leaving the door open to a very restrictive and repressive interpretation and urged the Egyptian authorities to consider amendments to the law "to make sure that any laws passed are in full conformity with international human rights standards".{{cite news|title=Amid ongoing Egyptian protests, UN chief urges rethinking anti-demonstrations law|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp/realfile/www.unesco.org/story.asp?NewsID=46609&Cr=Egypt&Cr1=#.Ur4eTvTuIl0|accessdate=27 December 2013|newspaper=[[UN News Centre]]|date=27 November 2013}} [[Guy Verhofstadt]], President of the [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group]] (ALDE), the third largest group in the [[European Parliament]], criticized the new law
This anti-protest law is against everything the revolution was about. The Egyptian government should withdraw it.{{cite news|title=Egypt is once again crossing the line|url=http://www.alde.eu/nc//press/speeches-speech-guy-verhofstadt/single-news/article/egypt-is-once-again-crossing-the-line-42668/|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group]]|date=27 November 2013}}
On 26 November, the No Military Trials for Civilians campaign organised a protest at the [[Shura Council]] in defiance of the protest law. The protest was violently dispersed by the police, and dozens of well-known activists were arrested.{{cite news|title=Egyptian police forcibly disperse protesters under new law curtailing demonstrations|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/egyptian-police-forcibly-disperse-protesters-under-new-law-curtailing-demonstrations/2013/11/26/4872452c-56cf-11e3-8304-caf30787c0a9_story.html/|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=26 November 2013}} The female activists were beaten and released on a desert road in the middle of the night,{{cite news|title=Interior Ministry denies releasing top female activists in desert|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/11/27/interior-minsitry-denies-releasing-top-female-activists-in-desert/|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Daily News Egypt]]|date=27 November 2013}} while the 24 male detainees remained in custody; most of whom were released on bail a week later.{{cite news|title=23 Shura detainees released on bail|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/12/04/23-shura-detainees-released-on-bail/|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Daily News Egypt]]|date=4 December 2013}} An arrest warrant was issued against Ahmed Maher on the following day, accusing him of inciting protests.{{cite news|title=Egypt prosecutor orders arrest of two leading activists|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/11/27/uk-egypt-protests-idUKBRE9AP0OI20131127/|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Reuters]]|date=27 November 2013}} Maher turned himself in and was detained on 30 November 2013.{{cite news|title=Egypt's Ahmed Maher, April 6 activist, turns himself in|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/middle-east/131130/ahmed-maher-april-6-egyptian-activist-turns-himself/|accessdate=30 November 2013|newspaper=[[Global Post]]|date=30 November 2013}} On 22 December 2013 an Egyptian court sentenced [[Ahmed Maher (youth leader)|Ahmed Maher]], [[Mohammed Adel (youth leader)|Mohammed Adel]], together with another prominent Egyptian activist, [[Ahmed Douma]], to three years in jail and EGP50,000 fine each.{{cite news|title=Egypt's Maher, Adel and Douma sentenced to 3 years in jail|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/89748/Egypt/Politics-/BREAKING-Three-leading-activists-sentenced-to-thre.aspx|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Ahramonline]]|date=22 December 2013}} Members of the April 6 movement and activists from other organizations have planned to initiate an open-ended sit-in with the intention of remaining in place until the protest law is repealed and the verdict sentencing Ahmed Maher, Mohamed Adel, and Ahmed Douma to three years in jail and the paymenent of a fine of LE50,000 have been overturned.{{Cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/98487/Egypt/Politics-/Sitin-against-protest-law-outside-presidential-pal.aspx|title=Sit-in against protest law outside presidential palace begins|agency=Ahram Online|date=7 April 2014|accessdate=7 April 2014}} Due to fears of a crackdown, the sit-in's timing and logistics have been rescheduled.{{Cite news|url=http://madamasr.com/content/sit-against-protest-law-suspended-protesters-regroup|title=Sit-in against protest law outside presidential palace begins|agency=Mada Masr|date=8 April 2014|accessdate=8 April 2014}}{{Cite news|url=http://thecairopost.com/news/105554/news/women-activists-politicians-protest-against-activist-detention|title=Women activists, politicians protest against activist detention|agency=The Cairo Post|date=8 April 2014|accessdate=8 April 2014}} ===Reactions to the verdict=== The verdicts were widely criticized nationally and internationally: The Cairo-based Arab Organization for Human Rights condemned the sentence saying it contradicts the spirit of the 25 January revolution.{{cite news|title= Egypt's Maher, Adel and Douma sentenced to 3 years in jail|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/89748.aspx|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Ahramonline]]|date=22 December 2013}} The Constitution Party has expressed solidarity with the detainees and their families and requested that the interim President Adly Mansour issue a pardon to Ahmed Maher, Mohammed Adel, and Ahmed Douma, as well as to Loay Abdel Rahman, Omar Hussein, Islam Ahmed, and Nasser Ibrahim.{{Cite news|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com//news/constitution-party-requests-president-mansour-pardon-arrested-activists|title=Constitution Party requests President Mansour to pardon arrested activists|agency=Egypt Independent|date=7 April 2014|accessdate=7 April 2014}} The [[Egyptian Social Democratic Party]], the [[Popular Current]], the [[Bread and Freedom Party]], and the [[Freedom for the Brave]] campaign have also lent their support to the cause of freedom for the imprisoned activists.{{Cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/98598/Egypt/Politics-/Political-groups-call-on-Egypts-president-to-pardo.aspx|title=Political groups call on Egypt's president to pardon jailed activists, revoke protest law|agency=Ahram Online|date=8 April 2014|accessdate=8 April 2014}} [[Hamdeen Sabahi]] has censured the court conviction sentencing Ahmed Maher, [[Mohammed Adel (youth leader)|Mohamed Adel]] and [[Ahmed Douma]] to three years in prison and a fine of LE50,000 and maintains that Interim President [[Adly Mansour]] should issue these and other detained individuals a pardon.{{Cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/98488/Egypt/Politics-/Presidential-candidate-demands-release-of-revoluti.aspx|title=Presidential candidate demands release of 'revolution activists'|agency=Ahram Online|date=7 April 2014|accessdate=7 April 2014}} The [[European Union]]: "The High Representative is concerned about the guilty verdict, the prison sentences and the financial penalty handed down by a court in Egypt against political activists Ahmed Maher, a founder of the April 6 Movement, Ahmed Douma and Mohammed Adel. These sentences appear to be based on the recently enacted protest law which is widely seen as limiting excessively freedom of expression and assembly. The High Representative expresses the hope that these sentences could be reviewed in an appeals process."{{cite news|title= Statement by the Spokesperson of EU High Representative Catherine Ashton on the sentencing of political activists in Egypt|url=http://www.eeas.europa.eu/statements/docs/2013/131223_01_en.pdf|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[European Union External Action]]|date=23 December 2013}} [[France]]: "France takes note of the harsh prison sentences handed down in the court of first instance to three human rights activists: Ahmed Maher, Ahmed Douma and Mohamed Adel. The handing down of these sentences follows the arrests carried out by the police – including on the premises of a human rights association –on the basis of the new law on demonstrations adopted on November 24.France shares the concerns expressed by the UN secretary-general and the UN high commissioner for human rights about this law. The sentences handed down yesterday confirm these concerns. France calls for compliance with the commitments undertaken by the Egyptian authorities in the context of the road map and at the international level with respect to public freedoms, notably the freedom of expression and opinion and the freedom to demonstrate peacefully while respecting public security requirements."{{cite news|title= Egypt – Sentencing of liberal activists |url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/egypt-288/events-5891/article/egypt-sentencing-of-liberal|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[France Diplomatie]]|date=23 December 2013}} [[Italy]]: "The Ministry for Foreign Affairs noted the Egyptian courts' conviction of three members of the opposition — Ahmed Maher, founder of the April 6th movement, and Ahmed Douma and Mohamed Adel — on charges associated with the protests. In reference to the Egyptian transition, Italy fully shares the stances taken by the United Nations and the European Union on the importance of respect for freedom of expression and the right to peaceful demonstration. Italy reconfirms its support for an inclusive and sustainable transition in Egypt aimed at the creation of a democratic society based on respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, and its willingness to engage in dialogue and cooperation to that end."{{cite news|title= Egyptian protesters convicted: Italy shares UN and EU stance on freedom of expression |url=http://www.esteri.it/MAE/EN/Sala_Stampa/ArchivioNotizie/Comunicati/2013/12/20131223_egcondespopp.htm|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Franesina-Ministero degli Affari Esteri]]|date=23 December 2013}} [[Norway]]: ""I am concerned about the yesterday's judgment against three Egyptian human rights activists. It is crucial that the Egyptian authorities respect democractic principles in this critical period prior to the elections and referendum on the constitution," said Minister of Foreign Affairs Børge Brende. The Egyptian authorities have taken action against democracy and human rights activists on several occasions recently. Yesterday, three prominent activists – Ahmed Maher, Ahmed Douma and Mohammed Adel – were sentenced to three years' imprisonment, and last week, employees and volunteers at the [[Centre for Economic and Social Rights]] were arrested in connection with a raid."{{cite news|title= Judgment against human rights activists in Egypt|url=http://www.regjeringen.no/en/dep/ud/press/news/2013/hr-activists-egypt.html?id=748577|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]|date=23 December 2013}} [[United Kingdom]]: "Foreign Office Minister Mark Simmonds expresses concern on the sentencing of three human rights activists in Egypt. Foreign Office Minister Mark Simmonds said: I was deeply concerned to hear about the sentencing to three years in prison of the democracy and human rights activists Ahmed Maher, Ahmed Douma and Mohammed Adel. This represents a serious setback to attempts to return Egypt to the democratic path and undermines the values expressed by Egyptians during the Revolution of January 2011. The UK believes the freedom to protest peacefully is vital in any democracy and calls on Egypt's interim leaders to ensure that they uphold all Egypt's international human rights obligations."{{cite news|title= FCO Minister responds to sentencing of Human Rights activists in Egypt|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/fco-minister-responds-to-sentencing-of-human-rights-activists-in-egypt|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[GOV.UK]]|date=23 December 2013}} [[United States]]: "The United States is deeply concerned about the worsening climate for freedom of assembly and peaceful expression in Egypt. The implementation of Egypt's restrictive demonstrations law has led to an increase in arrests, detentions, and charges against opposition figures, human rights activists and peaceful demonstrators, and sends a chilling message to civil society at large. In particular, we believe that the verdicts issued December 22 do not contribute to an open electoral environment or a transition process that protects the universal rights of all Egyptian citizens, and therefore should be reviewed. We continue to urge the government to fulfill its commitment to implement an inclusive democratic transition, including by permitting an open environment in which Egyptians are free to campaign and vote in favor or against the draft constitution on January 14–15, or abstain from the process entirely.{{cite news|title= State Dept. on Jail Sentences for Peaceful Egyptian Demonstrators|url=http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/texttrans/2013/12/20131223289431.html?CP.rss=true#axzz2oLGIQdo3|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=[[IIP Digital]]|date=23 December 2013}} ===Petition to repeal the protest law=== The April 6 movement has launched a campaign to annul the [[Egyptian protest law]] by a circulating a petition which citizens may sign to indicate approval for law's abolition or redrafting.{{cite news|title=6 April call for redrafting of Protest Law|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2014/03/23/6-april-call-redrafting-protest-law/|accessdate=25 March 2014|newspaper=[[Daily News Egypt]]|date=23 March 2014}}{{cite news|title=April 6 launches campaign to repeal protest law|url=http://thecairopost.com/news/103278/news/april-6-launches-campaign-to-repeal-protest-law|newspaper=Cairo Post|accessdate=25 March 2014|date=22 March 2014}} Leading functionaries from various political factions who have signed the petition include the president of the [[Constitution Party (Egypt)|Constitution Party]], [[Hala Shukrallah]], and Mohamed Ghonim, a key member of the [[Egyptian Social Democratic Party]].{{cite news|title=Hala Shukrallah signs April 6 petition against protest law|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/97517/Egypt/Politics-/Hala-Shukrallah-signs-April--petition-against-prot.aspx|newspaper=Ahram Online|accessdate=25 March 2014|date=25 March 2014}}{{cite news|title=April 6 petition against protest law draws prominent signatories|url=http://thecairopost.com/news/103681/news/april-6-petition-against-protest-law-draws-prominent-signatories|newspaper=Cairo Post|accessdate=25 March 2014|date=25 March 2014}} ===The split=== The '''April 6 Youth Movement Democratic Front''' ({{lang-ar|حركة شباب 6 أبريل الجبهة الديمقراطية}}) is an Egyptian activist group established in spring 2011 after the differences in the April 6 Youth Movement, led by [[Ahmed Maher (youth leader)|Ahmed Maher]]. Differences in the Movement started to appear in April when leaders of the movement announced they would transform it into a NGO or foundation on its anniversary. TV host and founder, Abd Alrahman Ezz, of 6 April "Democratic Front", told Ahram Online that the decision was taken without consultation. "It was taken with no respect for democracy, for the majority," Ezz says. The lack of internal democracy is the main reason why some left the mainstream movement, led by Ahmed Maher, forming the Democratic Front, Ezz says most of the old members joined the Democratic Front. On August 5th, a group of 6 April Youth Movement members in Alexandria announced that they had joined the Democratic Front, leaving the Ahmed Maher front due to what they considered discrimination in decision making processes. The split is not limited to Cairo and Alexandria but also seems to have been reproduced itself across the country. On August 6th, a group of April 6 Movement members in Kafr El-Sheikh governor announced that they joined the Democratic Front, leaving the Ahmed Maher Front. The same happened in Behaira and Port Said. ===The split leaders=== *Tarek Alkholy{{cite news|url=http://www.mbc.net/ar/mbc-maser/articles/%D9%88%D9%83%D9%8A%D9%84-%D9%85%D8%A4%D8%B3%D8%B3%D9%8A-%D8%AD%D8%B2%D8%A8--6-%D8%A5%D8%A8%D8%B1%D9%8A%D9%84---%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A5%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%8A%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%88%D9%84%D9%88%D9%86-%D8%AA%D8%B5%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B4%D9%87%D8%AF-%D8%B9%D8%A8%D8%B1-%D8%AC%D8%A8%D9%87%D8%A9--%D8%A3%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF-%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%B1--.html|title=mbc}} was a participant in the anti-[[Mohamed Morsi|Morsi]] demonstrations in [[Egypt]] in 2013.Esam Al-Amin, [http://www.dotmsr.com/details/%D8%A8%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%81%D9%8A%D9%84-%D8%B7%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%82-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D9%84%D9%8A-%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%B1%D8%AD%D9%85-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A9-%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%B6%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D8%B8%D8%A7%D9%85 From good-man to evil], Counterpunch, 4 February 2011 *Abd Alrahman Ezz escaped abroad after coup. *Shiref Alroby was jailed for four years in 2016 in a military jail.[http://www.youm7.com/story/2015/12/28/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%A8%D8%B6-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%B4%D8%B1%D9%8A%D9%81-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%A8%D9%89-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AF%D9%89-%D8%A8%D8%AD%D8%B1%D9%83%D8%A9-6-%D8%A5%D8%A8%D8%B1%D9%8A%D9%84/2513038#.VpK-Cvmqqko youm7] *Mohamed Tarek is founding member currently jailed for his witness of the massacre of the Rabeaa al Adawiya. {{Other uses|Army of God (disambiguation)}}
{{Infobox organization |name = Army of God |image = Donald Spitz holds Army of God Banner.jpg |size =200px |caption = Army of God spokesman [[Donald Spitz]] holds Army of God banner. |abbreviation = A.O.G. |motto = |formation = |headquarters = |coords = |type = [[Christian terrorism|Christian terrorist]] organization ([[anti-abortion violence]])
}} '''Army of God''' ('''AOG''') is a [[Christian terrorist]] organization that has engaged in the use of [[anti-abortion violence]] in the [[United States]] to fight against [[abortion]].<ref name="start">{{cite web | url = http://www.start.umd.edu/start/data_collections/tops/terrorist_organization_profile.asp?id=28 | title = Terrorist Organization Profile: Army of God | publisher = [[Homeland Security Centers of Excellence#The National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START)|National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism]] | accessdate = October 5, 2011 | archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/6AZjD1gRA?url=http://www.start.umd.edu/start/data_collections/tops/terrorist_organization_profile.asp?id=28# | archive-date = 2012-09-10 | dead-url = no | df = }}</ref><!--Contents copied from [[Anti-abortion violence]] article on April 25 2016--> According to the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] and [[Department of Homeland Security]]'s joint [[Terrorism Knowledge Base]], the Army of God is an active underground terrorist organization in the United States that was formed in 1982. In addition to numerous [[property crime]]s, the group has committed acts of [[kidnapping]], [[attempted murder]], and [[murder]]. While sharing a common [[ideology]] and tactics, the group's members claim that they rarely communicate with each other;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.start.umd.edu/tops/|title=Terrorist Organization Profile:Army of God|publisher=Terrorism Knowledge Base|date=2004–2008|accessdate=24 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924124458/http://www.start.umd.edu/tops/#|archive-date=2015-09-24|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> the organization forbids those who wish to "take action against baby killing abortionists" from discussing their plans with anyone in advance.<ref name=jefferis78>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ovBeXk1o9o8C&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78&dq=whatever+force+is+legitimate+to+defend+the+life+of+a+born+child+is+legitimate+to+defend+the+life+of+an+unborn+child&source=bl&ots=H0e7TUKLW2&sig=J636g_P7DAbR1qaMmUut5wNOkdA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMI6rDLpJOTyAIViA6SCh2m1wE1#v=onepage&q=whatever%20force%20is%20legitimate%20to%20defend%20the%20life%20of%20a%20born%20child%20is%20legitimate%20to%20defend%20the%20life%20of%20an%20unborn%20child&f=false |title=Armed for Life: The Army of God and Anti-Abortion Terror in the United States |last=Jefferis |first=Jennifer |date=2011 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |location=Santa Barbara}}</ref>
==Actions== The earliest documented incidence of the Army of God being involved with anti-abortion activity occurred in 1982. Three men stating that they were the "Army Of God"<ref name="Armed">{{cite book|last1=Jefferis|first1=Jennifer|title=Armed for Life: The Army of God and Anti-Abortion Terror in the United States|date=2011|publisher=Praeger|isbn=978-0313387531|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MNuQO-TWbt8C&pg=PA23&lpg=PA23&dq=Hector+Zevallos+%27%27army+of+God%27%27&source=bl&ots=f9eNtCBpXb&sig=qgbpL_p3YiU6FdSy6IX01fAI3C0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-6uqB-MzMAhVMHxoKHSjSAcIQ6AEIUjAJ#v=onepage&q=Hector%20Zevallos%20''army%20of%20God''&f=false|accessdate=9 May 2016}}</ref>{{rp|23}}<ref name="NYTJan83">{{cite news|title=ABORTION OPPOSITION STRESSED IN KIDNAPPING TRIAL IN ILLINOIS|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/26/us/abortion-opposition-stressed-in-kidnapping-trial-in-illinois.html|accessdate=9 May 2016|publisher=The New York Times|date=26 January 1983|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604055125/http://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/26/us/abortion-opposition-stressed-in-kidnapping-trial-in-illinois.html#|archive-date=2016-06-04|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> kidnapped Hector Zevallos, a doctor who performed abortions, and his wife, Rosalee Jean, and held them hostage. The hostages were later released unharmed after eight days.<ref name="baird">Baird-Windle, Patricia & Bader, Eleanor J., (2001), ''Targets of Hatred: Anti-Abortion Terrorism'', New York, St. Martin's Press, {{ISBN|978-0-312-23925-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kessler|first1=Ronald|title=The FBI|date=1993|publisher=Pocket Books|isbn=9781476746623|pages=279–280|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I9SN952mxpAC&pg=PA279&lpg=PA279&dq=kidnapped+Hector+Zevallos&source=bl&ots=7c6Kc5Xk8v&sig=K5zHx-MWsZ8_27dGsI6cne1MbSc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiNiOup4crMAhXMhRoKHf7tAUgQ6AEIOzAF#v=onepage&q=kidnapped%20Hector%20Zevallos&f=false|accessdate=8 May 2016}}</ref> The "East Coast division" of the AOG claimed responsibility when three men, including [[Michael Bray]], planted bombs at seven abortion clinics in Maryland, Virginia, and Washington D.C. in 1985.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/20/us/3-men-charged-in-bombings-of-seven-abortion-facilities.html |publisher=The New York Times |title=3 Men Charged in Bombings Of Seven Abortion Facilities |date=January 20, 1985 |access-date=2018-07-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171127204813/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/20/us/3-men-charged-in-bombings-of-seven-abortion-facilities.html# |archive-date=2017-11-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
In 1993, [[Shelly Shannon]], a very active member of the Army of God, was found guilty of the attempted murder of Dr. [[George Tiller]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Warner |first=Bill |title=Bill Warner Private Investigator Sarasota Fl to Panama City, Male & Female Detectives Dr. George Tiller Murdered by Army of God (AOG) Member, Shooting Suspect Scott P. Roeder Identified By Sheriff, AOG Alive And Well in Wichita Kansas. Bill Warner Private Investigator |date=May 31, 2009 |accessdate=November 22, 2009 |url=http://www.billwarnerpi.com/2009/05/dr-george-tiller-murdered-by-army-of.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712010828/http://www.billwarnerpi.com/2009/05/dr-george-tiller-murdered-by-army-of.html# |archive-date=2010-07-12 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> That same year, law enforcement officials found the ''Army of God Manual'', a tactical guide to arson, chemical attacks, invasions and bombings buried in Shelly Shannon's backyard.<ref name="baird" /> [[Paul Jennings Hill]] was found guilty of the murder of both Dr. [[John Britton (doctor)|John Britton]] and clinic escort James Barrett. The AOG claimed responsibility for [[Eric Robert Rudolph]]'s 1997 [[nail bomb]]ing of abortion clinics in [[Atlanta]] and [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]] as well as an Atlanta lesbian bar.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/US/9802/02/clinic.bombing.530pm/index.html?_s=PM:US |title=Army of God letters claim responsibility for clinic bombing |date=February 2, 1998 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=October 3, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151204113904/http://www.cnn.com/US/9802/02/clinic.bombing.530pm/index.html?_s=PM:US# |archive-date=2015-12-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
[[Clayton Waagner]], claiming to act on the part of the "Virginia Dare Chapter" of the AOG, mailed over 500 letters containing white powder to 280 abortion providers in 2001. The letters claimed that the powder was [[anthrax]]. Though it was not identified as such, the tactic took advantage of the public's fear of [[biological warfare]] after the recent [[2001 anthrax attacks|real anthrax attacks]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/1642930.stm | title=Analysis: Anthrax threat from within | publisher=BBC News | date=November 7, 2001 | accessdate=August 2, 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023050334/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/1642930.stm# | archive-date=2014-10-23 | dead-url=no | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/2100-201_162-317573.html | title={{-'}}Army Of God' Anthrax Threats | publisher=CBS News | date=November 9, 2001 | accessdate=August 2, 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031223409/http://www.cbsnews.com/2100-201_162-317573.html# | archive-date=2013-10-31 | dead-url=no | df= }}</ref>
The group is also associated with a number of other abortion clinic bombings, arsons and murders of abortion providers.<ref name="Armed"/>{{rp|25–26,38}} Some of those responsible claimed association with the AOG; in other cases, while the killers expressed no affiliation with the group, the AOG has endorsed their acts and taken up their cause, stating that any action which prevents abortion is justified.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE SECOND DEFENSIVE ACTION STATEMENT|url=http://www.armyofgod.com/defense2.html|publisher=Army of God|accessdate=9 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304053605/http://www.armyofgod.com/defense2.html#|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Hill was head of a precursor organization called [[Defensive Action]], which issued signed statements to members of Congress in the early 1990s expressing similar sentiments about "killing the killers".
==Documentary== The AOG movement, along with select followers, are featured in the HBO documentary film ''Soldiers in the Army of God'' (2000), directed by [[Marc Levin]] and Daphne Pinkerson, as part of HBO's [[America Undercover]] series.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/227103/Soldiers-in-the-Army-of-God/overview | title=Soldiers in the Army of God (2000) | publisher=New York Times | accessdate=8 July 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130227015459/http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/227103/Soldiers-in-the-Army-of-God/overview# | archive-date=2013-02-27 | dead-url=no | df= }}</ref>
==Associated individuals== *[[Michael Bray]] *[[Paul Jennings Hill]] *[[David Leach (activist)|David Leach]] *[[Scott Roeder]] *[[Eric Robert Rudolph]] *[[James Charles Kopp]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Kopp known as a radical|date=November 5, 1998|work=[[The Hamilton Spectator]]|page=A1|quote=It was in Atlanta that Kopp got his nickname "Atomic Dog," which was later featured in the acknowledgments of a manual showing anti-abortionists how to build bombs, make explosives and cut off the thumbs of abortion doctors. The manual was circulated by a loose association of extremists who called themselves the Army of God.}}</ref> *[[Shelley Shannon]] *[[Donald Spitz]] *[[Clayton Waagner]] *[[Fritz Springmeier]]<ref name=redden2009>{{cite news|author=Jim Redden |title=FBI probes alleged threat to officer |newspaper=[[Portland Tribune]] |date=October 30, 2009 |url=http://www.portlandtribune.com/news/story.php?story_id=2757 |archiveurl=https://thetribonline.net/news/print_story.php?story_id=2757 |archivedate=2013-04-19 |accessdate=2011-06-02 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> A 2011 [[NPR]] report claimed that an associate of this group, Stephen John Jordi, was imprisoned in a highly restrictive [[Communication Management Unit]].<ref name=npr2/>
